list.title: Question 1
list.content:
The amount of water, $W$, in litres, remaining in a cooking pot after it
is placed onto a hot stove is given by the function

$$
W(t) = 40(0.75)^t,\quad t\geq 0
$$

where $t$ is the time in hours after
the pot is placed on the stove.

- Find
  
  - the initial amount of water in the pot.
  - the percentage of water that leaves the pot in the form of steam
each hour. [3]


- Calculate the amount of water remaining in the pot after $5$ hours.
[2]

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The Burns, Gordons and Longstaff families make meal plans for their households. The table below shows the amount of carbohydrate, fat and protein, all measured in grams, consumed by the family over a single day. The table also shows the daily calories, measured in kcal, this equates to.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/350ffb2d-5f7c-4d42-9455-67a41e1ff452/images/8ca2d5dd-4221-43ed-b694-8407a3540349/1111a.JPG)


Let $x$, $y$ and $z$ represent the amount of calories, in kcal, for $1$ g of carbohydrate, fat and protein respectively.

- Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $x$, $y$ and $z$ that represents the information in the table above. [2]

- Find the values $x$, $y$ and $z$. [2]


The Howe family also plans meals. The table below shows the amount of carbohydrates, fat and protein consumed by the family over a single day.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/350ffb2d-5f7c-4d42-9455-67a41e1ff452/images/a0f40aa2-3fd5-4e46-b963-a74843eb2043/1111b.JPG)



- Calculate the daily calories for the Howe family. [2]

list.title: Question 3
list.content:
An ice cube was dropped into a cup of warm water. The weight of the ice
cube, $W$, in grams, reduces as the ice cube dissolves in the water. The
weight can be modelled by the following function, $W(t)$, where $t$ is
the time in seconds after the dissolving starts.

$$
W(t) =28(0.98)^t,\quad t\geq 0
$$


- Find
  
  - the initial weight of the ice cube.
  - the percentage of the ice cube dissolving every $5$ seconds.
[3]


- Calculate the weight of the ice cube remaining after one minute.
[2]

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
In an ecology experiment, a number of mosquitoes are placed in a
container with water and vegetation. The population of mosquitoes, $P$,
increases and can be modelled by the function

$$
P(t) = 24\times 4^{0.385t}, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0,
$$

where $t$ is
the time, in days, since the mosquitoes were places in the
container.

- Find the number of mosquitoes:
  
  - initially placed in the container;
  - in the container after $5$ days. [4]



The maximum capacity of the container is $5000$ mosquitoes.

- Find the number of days until the container reaches its
maximum capacity. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.3em} P(0) &= 24\times 4^{0.385(0)} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 24}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.3em} P(5) &= 24\times 4^{0.385(5)} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 346}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Solving the equation $P(t) = 5000$ for $t$, find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  24\times 4^{0.385t} &= 5000 \hspace{1.9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.3em} \answer{t \approx 10.0 \text{ days}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
After $1960$, the economy growth in Australia has grown in an
exponential fashion. Australian GDP per capita, $G(t)$, in United States
dollars (USD) is modelled by the function

$$
G(t) = 1806 \times (1.037)^t, \\[3pt]
$$

where $t$ is the number of
years since $1960$, and $t \geq 0$.

- Write down, in USD, Australian GDP per capita in $1960$. [1]

- Find Australian GDP per capita in $1961$. [1]

- Find the year for which Australian GDP per capita reaches
$100\hspace{0.15em}000$ USD. Give your answer correct to the
nearest year. [4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{1806 \text{ USD}}$
- Evaluating $G(t)$ for $t = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.7em} G(1) &= 1806 \times (1.037) \\[6pt]
  &= 1872.822 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 1870 \text{ USD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $G(t) = 100\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} 1806 \times (1.037)^t &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 110 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence Australian GDP per capita reaches $100\hspace{0.15em}000$ USD
in  $\answer{2070}$

list.title: Question 6
list.content:
The sound intensity level, $D$, in decibels (dB), can be modelled by the
function

$$
D(I) = 10\log_{10}(I) + 120, \hspace{0.5em} I \geq 0,

$$

where
$I$ is the sound intensity, in watts per square meter
(W $/$m$^2$).

- A vacuum cleaner has a sound intensity of $1.6\times10^{-5}$
W $/$m$^2$. Calculate the intensity level of
the vacuum cleaner. [2]

- A fire truck siren has an intensity level of $124$ dB. Find the
sound intensity of the siren. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $D(I)$ for $I = 1.6\times10^{-5}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.2em} D\left(1.6\times10^{-5}\right) &= 10\log_{10}\left(1.6\times10^{-5}\right) + 120 \\[8pt]
  &\answer{\approx 72.0 \text{ dB}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(I) = 124$ for $I$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  10\log_{10}(I) + 120 &= 124 \hspace{5.8em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15em} \answer{I \approx 2.51 \text{ W\hspace{-0.1em}$/$m$^2$}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 7
list.content:
Oliver throws a coin from the open window onto flat horizontal ground in
front of his office building.
The path of the coin is modelled by the quadratic curve
$y = 8 + 3x - 0.5x^2$ , where $x$ represents the
horizontal distance the coin is thrown and $y$ represents the height of
the coin above the ground. All distances are measured in metres. The
wall of the building lies along the $y$-axis. The coin starts its flight
at point A, reaches its maximum height at point B, and lands on the
ground at point C, as shown on the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/551a9c07-a2a1-4842-bd91-826ca4e267b9/images/be672629-0ece-49eb-b0ba-8f5c76b93870/3194f4c38ebe70fcc80ad86fb61b4fd630cd08ef.svg)



- Write down the height in metres from which the coin was thrown.
[1]

- Calculate the maximum height, above the ground, reached by the coin.
[3]

- Find the horizontal distance from the base of the wall to the point
at which the coin hits the ground. [2]

list.title: Question 8
list.content:
The average daily hours of sunlight, $S$, during a 12-month period in a
particular town is given by the function

$$
S(t)=a\cos(bt-180)+d,

$$

where
time, $t$, is measured in months, $a$ and $d$ are constants, and $b$ is
measured in degrees.
The graph of $S$ versus $t$ is shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8a6e0bdd-88f9-4d71-8c34-6feeedb1d7e0/images/4284ab68-f212-4ca3-8085-e16d1ab13767/aff649079ad71d825a6dc0770f6728fb76b7cce5.svg)



- Find the value of
  
  - $a$;
  - $d$. [2]


- Find the value of $b$. [2]

- Write down the values of $t$ when the average daily sunlight is $10$
hours. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Using the graph of $S$ versus $t$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    a &=\dfrac{1}{2}(S_\text{max}-S_\text{min}) \\[6pt]
    &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(16-4) \\[6pt]
    % &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(12) \\[6pt]
    & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=6}
    \end{aligned}
    $$

  - Using the graph of $S$ versus $t$, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    d &=\dfrac{1}{2}(S_\text{max}+S_\text{min}) \\[6pt]
    &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(16+4) \\[6pt]
    %   &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(20) \\[6pt]
    & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=10}
    \end{aligned}
    $$


- The period of $S$ is 12 months. Hence, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &=\dfrac{\ang{360}}{\text{period}} \\[6pt]
  &=  \dfrac{\ang{360}}{12} \\[6pt]
  % &=  \dfrac{1}{2}(12) \\[6pt]
  & \hspace{0.525em}\answer{=\ang{30}}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- The graph of $S$ versus $t$ shows that $S(3) =10$ and $S(9) =10$.
Hence, the average daily sunlight hours is 10 for
$\answer{t=3\hspace{0.525em}\text{and}\hspace{0.525em} t=9.}$

list.title: Question 9
list.content:
A toy rocket is fired, from a platform, vertically into the air, its height above the ground after $t$ seconds is given by $s(t) = at^2 + bt + c$, where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{R}$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bb0065fc-bc20-4898-a580-9d8d84f4cc81/images/26a3d948-9010-49f6-b623-7aac14c767bf/rocket.png)


After $2$ second, the rocket is $28.3$ m above the ground; after $4$ seconds, $25.6$ m; after $5$ seconds, $14.7$ m.

- 
  - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$.
  - Hence find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [3]


- Find the height, above the ground, of the platform. [1]

- Find the time it takes for the rocket to hit the ground. [2]

list.title: Question 10
list.content:
A population of $50$ hamsters was introduced to a new town. One month
later, the number of hamsters was $62$. The number of hamsters, $P$, can
be modelled by the function

$$
P(t) = 50\times b^t,\hspace{0.5em} t\geq0, \\[3pt]
$$

where $t$ is the
time, in months, since the hamsters were introduced to the town.

- Find the value of $b$. [2]

- Calculate the number of hamsters in the town after $6$ months.
[2]


A wildlife specialist estimates that the town has enough drink and food
to support a maximum population of $2000$ hamsters.

- Calculate the number of months it takes for the hamster
population to reach this maximum. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Solving the equation $P(1) = 62$ for $b$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times b^1 &= 62 \hspace{2.1em} \\[6pt]
  b &= \dfrac{62}{50} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.4em}\answer{b = 1.24}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 6$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.2em} P(6) &= 50\times(1.24)^6 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 182}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 2000$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50\times(1.24)^t &= 2000 \hspace{3.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{15.6em} \answer{t \approx 17.1 \text{ months}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 11
list.content:
The average time, $T$, in seconds, it takes for a customer to find their
favourite menu item in an alphabetical menu list can be modelled by the
function

$$
\begin{aligned}
T(n) &= \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(n+1), \hspace{0.5em} n \geq 1,\end{aligned}
$$

where $n$ is the number of different menu items in the list.
Mehmet visits Taste of Adana Restaurant for the first time to have a
lunch.

- The restaurant serves $10$ different fresh salads. Find the time it
takes for Mehmet to find Persian Salad in the Fresh Salads section
of the menu list. [2]

- It takes $7.5$ seconds for Mehmet to find Lamb Chops Kebab in the
Adana Kebab section of the menu list. Find the number of different
kebab dishes served by the restaurant. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(n)$ for $n = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} T(10) &= \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(10+1) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 5.19 \text{ seconds}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(n) = 7.5$ for $n$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{3}{2}\log_2(n+1) &= 7.5 \hspace{6.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.45em} \answer{n = 31} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 12
list.content:
An eagle is sitting in her nest and scanning the area for prey.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/beb96113-bce6-4e9f-96f9-57c723565e26/eagle.png)


The height, $h$, of the eagle above the ground, in metres, is modelled by the following quadratic function.
$h(t)=1.8t^2-8.7t+14$, $t \geq 0$
where $t$ is the time in seconds after the eagle begins to move.

- Write down the height above the ground of the eagles nest. [1]

- The eagle sees a dormouse and swoops down to try and catch it, however, the dormouse runs away and the eagle returns back to the nest.
  
  - How high above the ground was the eagle when it turned around and went back to the nest?
  - How long does it take for the eagle to return to the nest, from the time it left the nest? [4]
list.markScheme:
- The eagle is initially in her nest, that is at $t=0$. Therefore her height is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      h(0)&=1.8\times(0)^2-8.7\times(0)+14\\
      &=14
  \end{align*}
  $$

The nest is $\answer{14\,\text{m}}$ above the ground.
- 
  - The eagle turns around and returns to the nest at the minimum point of $h(t)$ with the $y$-coordinate being the height above the ground at this moment.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/b14f56e1-7645-4a85-a4f1-c17abecdf0c8/para1.png)


    The eagle was $\answer{3.49\,\text{m}}$ above the ground when it turned around.
  - The nest is $14$m above the ground. By solving $h(t)=14$ we can find the time the eagle arrives back at the nest.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/36821331-1fa8-495a-bc0b-36afa80ad28c/images/e5dafd1a-8037-4edf-9ab2-63ad77102b02/para2.png)


    The eagle took $\answer{4.83\,\text{s}}$ to return to the nest.

list.title: Question 13
list.content:
The orbital velocity, $v$, of a spacecraft in km/s is given by

$$
v = -0.0098t + c \ln R,
$$

where $t$ is the firing time in seconds, $c$
is the exhaust velocity in km/s and $R$ is the mass ratio.
If $R=30$, find

- The orbital velocity, $v$, after a firing time of 150 seconds and an
exhaust velocity of 3 km/s. [2]

- The exhaust velocity, $c$, of the spacecraft traveling at an orbital
velocity of $9.5 \text{ km/s}$ after a firing time of 150 seconds.
[3]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting in $t=150$, $c=3$ and $R=30$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  v &= -0.0098(150) + (3) \ln (30)\hspace{0.5cm}\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx 8.73 \text{ km/s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting in $v=9.5$, $t=150$ and $R=30$, we can solve for $c$

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  9.5 &= -0.0098(150) + c \ln (30)\hspace{0.5cm}\\[8pt]
  c \ln (30) &= 9.5 + 0.0098(150)\\[8pt]
  c &= \dfrac{9.5+0.0098(150)}{\ln (30)}\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx 3.23 \text{ km/s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 14
list.content:
In the realm of Artificial Intelligence (AI), machine learning models are trained using data sets. The time taken to train a machine learning model is directly proportional to the size of the training data set. This is shown by the following:

$$
\begin{align*}
t &\propto x
\end{align*}
$$

Where $t$ is training time in hours, and $x$ is the size of the training data set in gigabytes.
It is known that a certain machine learning model takes $15$ hours to train using a data set of size $100$ gigabytes.

- Find an equation for $t$ in terms of $x$. [2]

- If a dataset of 250 gigabytes is used, determine the expected training time. [2]


The larger the data set that is used for training, the more effective the machine learning model is deemed to be.
A new and improved training model has been developed, so that a machine learning model can be trained in the same amount of time as the previous model, using larger data sets. The equation for the new model is $t=0.1x$.

- Given a training time of $20$ hours, determine the difference in the size of the data sets between the first and second machine learning models.   [3]

list.title: Question 15
list.content:
The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a harbour on a particular day can be
modelled by the equation

$$
D = 2.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \\[3pt]
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight.

- Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below. [2]

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/847eec72-676b-4606-a4fb-3dcfedc9b6da/images/4265cedf-520e-4467-bdb0-2d56bcfc7630/19fd3a817fff397619c38bc3f6d8f3794089c50d.svg)


- Find the lowest and highest depths of water in the harbour, and the
times when they occur. [2]

- A large yacht has a draught of $3$ metres. Decide whether the yacht
will be able to enter the harbour at $5$ pm. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/847eec72-676b-4606-a4fb-3dcfedc9b6da/images/ba52a231-78e9-46b9-857b-1237e71c6260/99ad31616997cbd93f3b2bcca5b2e21cec1a56b5.svg)


- From the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid above, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{D_{\text{min}} = 2.5 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 6, 18} \\[6pt]
  \hspace{4.2em} \answer{D_{\text{max}} = 7.5 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 0, 12, 24}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $D$ when $t = 17$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} D &= 2.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 17) + 5 \\[6pt]
  &= 2.5\cos 5\ang{10} + 5 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 2.83\text{ m} \\[6pt]
  &< 3 \text{ m}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the yacht
$\answer{\text{will not be able}}$
to enter the harbour at $5$ pm.

list.title: Question 16
list.content:
The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a harbour on a particular can be
modelled by the equation

$$
D = 3\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24, \\[3pt]
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight.

- Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below. [2]

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aa0d706-15a7-45ce-b7c4-c439903d95d0/images/88525833-f18f-4bc6-8659-178e0c8217ce/bc607b763c6a7abff0abf4c7db110b192240d1a3.svg)


- Find the lowest and highest depths of water in the harbour, and the
times when they occur. [2]

- A large boat has a draught of $2.5$ metres. Decide whether the boat
will be able to enter the harbour at $8$ pm. [2]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aa0d706-15a7-45ce-b7c4-c439903d95d0/images/c2909ae5-a8e9-4c71-8012-36bfe1b65413/5c4bc36227599f18aecea5fee37d5db9b328bd33.svg)


- From the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid above, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \answer{D_{\text{min}} = 2 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 9, 21} \\[6pt]
  \hspace{1.35em} \answer{D_{\text{max}} = 8 \text{ m}}\hspace{0.525em} &\text{ when }\hspace{0.525em}\answer{t = 3, 15}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $D$ when $t = 20$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em} D &= 3\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 20) + 5 \\[6pt]
  &= 3\sin 600\text{\textdegree} + 5 \\[6pt]
  &\approx 2.40\text{ m} \\[6pt]
  &< 2.5 \text{ m}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the boat
$\answer{\text{will not be able}}$
to enter the harbour at $8$ pm.

list.title: Question 17
list.content:
The size of the trunk diameter of a chestnut oak tree, $d$, in
centimetres, can be modelled by the function

$$
d(t) = 9\ln(0.25\hspace{0.05em}t), \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 5, \\[3pt]
$$

where $t$ is the age, in years, of the tree.

- Find the size of the trunk diameter of a $10$-year-old chestnut oak
tree.[2]

- The size of the trunk diameter of a chestnut oak tree is
$15$ cm. Find its age. [2]


A chestnut oak tree can be harvested for wood when the size of its trunk
diameter reaches $20$ cm.

- Find the age of the chestnut oak tree when it is old enough
to be harvested for timber. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $d(t)$ for $t = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d(10) &= 9\ln(0.25(10)) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8.25 \hspace{0.25em}\text{ cm}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $d(t) = 15$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  9\ln(0.25\hspace{0.05em}t) &= 15 \hspace{7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.1em} \answer{t = 21.2 \text{ years}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $d(t) = 20$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  9\ln(0.25\hspace{0.05em}t) &= 20 \hspace{7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.1em} \answer{t = 36.9 \text{ years}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 18
list.content:
A water tank has a float valve that allows water to enter while the tank is not full.  Over time, the float valve reduces the water flow until the tank is almost at its maximum capacity.
The amount of water in the tank, in litres, is given by the function $W(t)=5\,000-C\left(1.04^{-t}\right)$
where $t$ is minutes after the tank starts to fill.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b93229be-02cb-4ca6-90cd-091a590021f8/images/206420d5-addd-4321-a0d4-63591b3fa52a/779.JPEG)



- Given that the tank was initially empty, find the value of $C$.[2]

- State what the horizontal asymptote represents in the context of the question.[1]

- Find the total amount of water in the tank after one and half hours. Give your answer in cubic metres. [3]

list.title: Question 19
list.content:
An owl takes off from from a tree branch and flies higher into the sky. Its height above the ground after $t$ seconds, where $t\geq 0$, is given by $s(t) = at^3 + bt^2 + ct+d$, where $a,b,c,d \in \mathbb{R}$ and $s(t)$ is measured in metres.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f2f10540-8736-484c-b76e-293673a1a920/images/e10ba209-e2d4-4ca9-a89f-fc01ced21fb2/owl.png)


Initially the owl is $12\,$ metres above the ground.

- Write down the value of $d$.   [1]  

After $1$ second, the owl is $19.8$ m above the ground; after $2$ seconds, $34.5$ m; after $4$ seconds, $22.8$ m.

- 
  - Write down a system of three linear equations in terms of $a$, $b$ and $c$.
  - Hence find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$.  [3]



After some time the owl reaches a maximum height. At this time it spots some prey at ground level and then immediately swoops down to catch it.

- 
  - Find the maximum height of the owl above the ground as it spots the prey.
  - Find the time it catches the prey. [2]

list.title: Question 20
list.content:
The diagram below shows the graph of a quadratic function
$f(x) = 2x^2 + bx + c$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f982a52-59ba-4f95-a36a-b780904e0f9b/images/45767584-5045-4282-ac7c-db20e0fb8792/75e0c507b59edc93cc9f79e429c580e90c045817.svg)



- Write down the value of $c$. [1]

- Find the value of $b$ and write down $f(x)$. [3]

- Calculate the coordinates of the vertex of the graph of $f$.
[2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{c = -30}$
- The graph of $f$ passes through the point P$(3,0)$.
Hence, using the coordinates of P, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(3) &= 0 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  2(3)^2 + b(3) - 30 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  18 + 3b - 30 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  3b - 12 &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{4em} \answer{b = 4}
  $$

  Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.4em} \answer{f(x) = 2x^2 + 4x - 30}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The axis of symmetry of the graph of $f$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em}  x &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \\[6pt]
  x &= -\dfrac{4}{2(2)} \\[8pt]
  x &= -1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $f(x)$ for $x = -1$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.65em} f(-1) &= 2(-1)^2 + 4(-1) - 30 \\[6pt]
  &= -32\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the coordinates of the vertex are
$\answer{(-1,-32)}$

list.title: Question 21
list.content:
The tip of a large wind turbine's blade rotates at a constant speed on a
windy day. Its height, $H$ , in metres, above
the ground is modelled by the function

$$
H(t) = 52\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{60}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 80,
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in seconds, since the turbine was
accelerated to its max speed.

- Write down the minimum height of the blade's tip above the ground.
[2]

- Find the height of the blade's tip above the ground after $8$
seconds. [2]

- Find the time it takes for the blade's tip to complete one full
revolution. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The min value of the sine function is $-1$.
Hence the min height of the blade's tip is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  H_{\text{min}} &= 52(-1) + 80 \hspace{1.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 28\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $H(t)$ for $t = 8$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em} H(8) &= 52\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{60}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 8) + 80 \\[6pt]
  &= 52\sin \ang{480} + 80 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 125\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/345633bb-e844-436b-bd39-eff8642672ef/images/5f3d01f7-4c01-4f77-b034-46af9d83cc7a/279de316931380f9a5da6848695c261465d527a8.svg)


  Hence it takes
$\answer{6 \text{ seconds}}$
for the blade's tip to complete one full revolution.

list.title: Question 22
list.content:
The magnitude of an earthquake, $M$, on the Richter scale, can be
modelled by the function

$$
M(E) = \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(E) - 3.2, \\[3pt]
$$

where $E$ is the
amount of energy, in joules, released by the earthquake.

- Find the magnitude of an earthquake which releases
$6.3\times10^{13}$ joules of $\text{energy}$. [2]


The Great Chilean Earthquake of $1960$, the most powerful earthquake
recorded in the $20$th century, had a magnitude of $9.5$ on the Richter
scale.

- Find the amount of energy, in joules, released by the Great
Chilean $\text{Earthquake}$.   [2]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $M(E)$ for $E = 6.3\times10^{13}$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6em} M(E) &= \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(6.3\times10^{13}) - 3.2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 6.00}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $M(E) = 9.5$ for $E$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{2}{3}\log_{10}(E) - 3.2 &= 9.5 \hspace{7.85em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{14.2em} \answer{E \approx 1.12\times10^{19} \text{ joules}} \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 23
list.content:
Jack, a volleyball player, serves the ball with a trajectory modelled by the function

$$
h_1(x)=-0.12x^2+x+0.725
$$

where $h$ is the height of the ball above the ground, in metres, and $x$ is the horizontal distance from the serving point, in metres.

- Find the height of the ball when Jack makes his serve (i.e. the height above the ground at the point where he connects with the ball).[2]  

Unfortunately, the serve is short and misses. For his next attempt, Jack will serve the ball $c$ metres higher at the serving point, so that the ball has the same trajectory (only the vertical height changes, increasing by $c$ metres).

- Write down a second function, $h_2(x)$, modelling the new path of the ball in terms of $x$ and $c$.[1]

- 
  - Calculate  the value of $c$, if the horizontal distance is $10$ metres from the serving point to the point where the ball would hit the ground.
  - Determine the vertical height of the ball from which Jack makes his successful serve.[4]

list.title: Question 24
list.content:
A house located in a town experiencing drought issues features a square-shaped roof, with each side being $x$ meters.
The roof is able to catch and store rainwater.
During a rainfall, it is known that the mean amount of rainwater ($W$ in litres) collected is directly proportional to the square of $x$.
It is known that the system can collect $19\hspace{0.15em}845$ litres when the value of $x$ is $7$ metres.

- Find an equation for $W$ in terms of $x$.  [2]  

The formula found in part (a) can be used to determine the mean amount of rainwater ($W$ in litres) collected by other houses in the town with a square roof.

- Determine the side length of a square roof that has collected $32\hspace{0.1em}805$ litres during a rainfall.   [3]
list.markScheme:
- According to the description we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      W &= cx^2 \\
      19\hspace{0.15em}845 &= c(7)^2 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
      c &= \dfrac{19\hspace{0.15em}845}{49} \\[6pt]
      c &= 405\\[-10pt]
  \end{align*}
  $$

Therefore, the formula is $\answer{W(x)=405x^2}$

  $$
      \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$


$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- Substituting $W=32\hspace{0.1em}805$ into our equation from part (a), we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
      32\hspace{0.1em}805 &= 405x^2 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}}\\[6pt]
      x^2 &= \dfrac{32\hspace{0.1em}805}{405} \\[6pt]
      &= 81 \tag*{\textbf{(M1)}} \\[6pt]
      &\hspace{-0.5em}\tcbhighmath{x = 9\hspace{0.15em}\text{m}}\tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 25
list.content:
Atmospheric pressure, $P$, in kPa, decreases exponentially with
increasing height above sea level, $h$. The atmospheric pressure can be
modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(h) &= 101\times\bigg(\dfrac{25}{22}\bigg)^{-h},\end{aligned}
$$

where
$h$ is the height above sea level in kilometres.

- Write down the exact atmospheric pressure at sea level, in kPa.
[1]


Mount Kosciuszko is the highest mountain in Australia with a height of
$2228$ $\text{metres}$ above sea level at the top.

- Calculate the atmospheric pressure at the top of the Mount
Kosciuszko. [2]

- Calculate the height where the atmospheric pressure is
equal to $10$ kPa. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{101 \text{ kPa}}$
- Evaluating $P(h)$ for $h = 2.228$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.6em} P(2.228) &= 101\times\bigg(\dfrac{25}{22}\bigg)^{-2.228} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 76.0 \text{ kPa}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(h) = 10$ for $h$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  101\times\bigg(\dfrac{25}{22}\bigg)^{-h} &= 10 \hspace{8.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11em} \answer{h = 18.1\hspace{0.25em}\text{km}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 26

list.title: Question 28
list.content:
The total cost of a gym membership, $C$, in Australian dollars (AUD), in
John's Gym can be modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
C = 65t +30,\end{aligned}
$$

where $t$ is the time in months.

- Calculate the gym membership cost over a $6$ month duration.
[1]

- On the grid below, sketch the graph of the function $C = 65t + 30$,
for $t\geq0$. [2]

grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/242b7846-dd0a-4322-956c-9edf06d9bc3f/images/92290ff7-7fd4-46b2-b43d-07393fff434a/ffcb3caa4ff34c194a63936e0581df79e4c6a499.svg)

  $$

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{John's Gym}:& \hspace{1.0em} C = 65t + 30 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]

  If we sketch the graphs of $(1)$ and $(2)$, for $t \geq 0$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have

list.title: Question 29
list.content:
The subscription fee for an online project management software by
AB-Tech is $\$ 40$ per month. If the customer buys for a whole year in
advance, a discount of $\$130$ is applied.
This can be modelled by the following function, $P(n)$, which gives the
total cost when paying annually for the subscription.

$$
P(n) = 40n - 130,\quad n\geq 12
$$

where $n$ is the number months.

- Find the total cost of buying a subscription for $2$ years.
[2]

- Find $P^{-1}(1790)$. [2]


The subscription price for a different online project management tool by
YZ-tech is $\$35$ per month, however customers can only purchase
annually in advance, and there are no discounts. The total subscription
cost of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's software when $n>k$ .

- Find the minimum value of $k$.   [3]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $n=24$ into the $P(n)$ function, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(n) &=40n-130\\[6pt]
  P(24) &= 40(24)-130 \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.5em}\answer{=\$ 830}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Let's denote $P(n)$ by $y$. To find the inverse we can interchange
the variables $n$ and $y$ and rearrange for $y$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 40n-130 \\[6pt]
  n&=40y-130\\[6pt]
  40y&=n+130\\[6pt]
  y&=\dfrac{n+130}{40}\\[6pt]
  P^{-1}(n) &= \dfrac{n+130}{40}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We can now find
$P^{-1}(1790)$ as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P^{-1}(1790)&=\dfrac{1790+130}{40}\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-3.5em}\answer{P^{-1}(1790)=48 \text{ months}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- For AB-tech's software we we were given the pricing function

  $$
  P(n)=40n-130
  
  $$

  For YZ-tech, we can define the function, $S(n)$, to
represent the subscription price for their software

  $$
  S(n)=35n
  $$

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2b908e8c-786e-4fec-844c-19b9653ea308/images/7386b1f2-6825-49b7-88df-da2a1e5501e7/7402d7e1fc9d51e4e9f6b0f5ea74f75143d1438e.svg)


  From the graph, $S(n) < P(n)$ for $n>26$.
  The price of YZ-tech's software is less than AB-tech's when $n>26$.
  Therefore,  $\answer{k=26}$

list.title: Question 30

Jasper owns a business and has 7 employees. He can assign any number of employees to a task. The time the task takes varies inversely with the number of employees who are assigned to it. This is shown by the following:

Where $t$ is time a task takes in hours, and $x$ is the number of employees assigned to the task.

list.title: Question 31
list.content:
Tom has a model train set, which includes a tunnel that the model train must pass through. The entrance of the tunnel is in the shape of the parabola $h(x)=-0.6x^2+3.12x$, where $h$ is the height of the tunnel in centimetres, and $x$ is the horizontal distance from the bottom left corner of the tunnel entrance at $(0,0)$, also in centimetres.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b56be12-9b7e-47a6-8d33-db4ce1696bee/images/987cf5eb-a4ea-4400-b222-435b2427a3c5/AI1017a.PNG)



- Find the equation of the axis of symmetry of the parabola that models the tunnel entrance. [2]  

Tom is considering purchasing a new carriage for his model train. The carriage is in the shape of a cuboid with a height of $3.5\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}$ and a width of $2\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}$.

- Determine whether the carriage will fit through the tunnel entrance. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Using the formula for the axis of symmetry of a quadratic function, with $a=-0.6$ and $b=3.12$, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x &= - \dfrac{b}{2a} \\[11pt]
  &= - \dfrac{3.12}{(2)(-0.6)} \\[11pt]
  & \hspace{-0.55em}\tcbhighmath{x = 2.6}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Since the height of the carriage is $3.5\hspace{0.25em}\text{cm}$ we can find the available horizontal width by finding the intersection of the parabola with the line $y=3.5$. Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4b56be12-9b7e-47a6-8d33-db4ce1696bee/images/0c8e24b3-697a-4ff7-9ac8-0f36449f9dc2/AI1017b.PNG)


  Since the length of segment AB is $3.563-1.637=1.926$, and $1.926<2$, we conclude that $\answer{\text{the carriage will not be able to fit through the tunnel entrance.}}$

list.content:
The cross-section of a ship's hull below the surface of the ocean can be modelled by a parabola. The depth of the boat's hull, $d$ metres, is given by $d(x) = 0.5x^2-6.4x$, where $x$ is the horizontal distance from the left-hand side of the hull at the surface, also in metres, as shown in the following diagram. The $x$-axis represents the ocean surface.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50b7a549-0fae-4e88-8198-43d4e8b67c4a/images/cb400f16-0845-431b-94dc-26dd2eb56467/AI1018a.PNG)

- Determine the maximum width of a container that the ship can transport on the storage deck, given that the container is $10$ metres high. Give your answer to the nearest metre.   [3]

  \end{align*}
  $$

- Since the depth of the storage deck is $10\hspace{0.25em}\text{m}$, we can find the available horizontal width by finding the intersection of the parabola with the line $y=-10$. Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/50b7a549-0fae-4e88-8198-43d4e8b67c4a/images/0c8115e4-bb78-4db4-b0b4-d73febbc287e/AI1018b.PNG)


  Since the length of segment AB is $10.98 - 1.822 = 9.158$ we conclude:
  The maximum width of a transportable container that is $10$ metres high is $9$ metres.

list.title: Question 33
list.content:
The total cost of a ride, $C$, in British pounds (GBP), on BlackCabs can

of $\text{\(C\hspace{-0.15em}=\hspace{-0.15em}1.75x\hspace{-0.15em}+\hspace{-0.15em}3.00\)}$, for $\text{\(x\hspace{-0.15em}\geq\hspace{-0.15em}0\)}$, on the grid $\text{below}$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6340868f-a8d3-4dff-a066-c93ed0c4bad4/images/b628cbad-3d33-4732-a1c3-7206661a40ba/0fbc572f5386caf92a0b3a37fe873d0c550a8cee.svg)


- Solving the equation $C = 45$ for $x$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1.75x + 3.00 &= 45 \hspace{6.95em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.2em} \answer{x = 24 \text{ km}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{BlackCab}:& \hspace{1.0em} C = 1.75x + 3.00 \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  \text{MiniCab}:& \hspace{1.0em} C = 1.40x + 5.00 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we sketch the graphs of $(1)$ and $(2)$, for $x \geq 0$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6340868f-a8d3-4dff-a066-c93ed0c4bad4/images/48426bc3-2d7a-45b4-bfc3-9e0988433f8c/e7c289a4de8f1b0042a6607943738c5b0d6aeabd.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(6\) km}}$
is required to travel for the total cost of the ride to be
  less on a MiniCab than on a BlackCab.

list.title: Question 34
list.content:
The Mohs scale of mineral hardness is a qualitative, discrete scale characterizing the scratch resistance of various minerals through the ability of harder materials to scratch softer ones. It ranges from talc (1), the softest mineral, to diamond (10), the hardest.  Minerals are assigned a whole number value on the Mohs scale.
Absolute hardness of a mineral quantifies its resistance to scratching on a continuous scale, providing a more precise measurement than the Mohs scale.
The relationship between Mohs scale score, $M$, and absolute hardness, $H$, is given by

$$
\begin{align*}
0.319M &= \log_{10}H-0.117
\end{align*}
$$


- Calculate the Mohs scale score for quartz, which has an absolute hardness of 100. Give your answer to the nearest whole number.	 [2]

- Find $H$ as a function of $M$.[2]

- Calculate the absolute hardness of fluorite, which has a Mohs scale score of 4.[2]

- Hence determine how many times greater the absolute hardness of quartz is than the absolute hardness of fluorite.[2]

list.title: Question 35
list.content:
Two identical water waves pass a sensor in an oceanography laboratory.
As the waves pass the sensor, the
depth, $D$, in metres, of water is recorded
and modelled by the function

$$
D(t) = 3.21-0.45\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{24.2}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t)
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in seconds, since the first wave hit the
sensor.

- Find the minimum and maximum depths of the water as the two waves
pass the sensor. [3]

- Find the first time after $16$ seconds at which the depth of water
reaches $\text{\(3.5\)\hspace{0.25em}m}$.[3]
list.markScheme:
- The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max depths of water are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D_{\text{min}} &= 3.21-0.45(+1) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 2.76 \text{ m}} \\[15pt]
  \hspace{1em} D_{\text{max}} &= 3.21-0.45(-1) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 3.66 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(t) = 3.5$ for first $t > 16$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3.21-0.45\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{24.2}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) &= 3.5 \hspace{13em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{8.6em} \answer{t \approx 20.3} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 36
list.content:
Coral is a wildlife expert who tags  flying fish and records their movement using an electronic device.
The tagging device tells her the height of a fish relative to the water level, at any given time.
She knows that the fish swim mostly in the water, but occasionally they fly (jump!) out of the water.
The height is measured in metres and the time in seconds. If the height is negative the fish is under the water, if the height is positive the fish is flying.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/99db50ab-81ea-421b-8f20-21b4669fedcd/images/70f02a92-7870-456a-abea-c262c3ce2d2b/seagull.png)


Coral notices one particular fish as it flies out of the water. The moment it re-enters the water the device begins tracking its height.
At $2$ seconds the fish is at a height of $-2.8\,$m; at $5$ seconds the fish is at a height of $-2\,$m and at $11$ seconds the fish is also at a height of $-2\,$m.
The height of the fish can be expressed as $H(t)=at^3+bt^2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d \in \mathbb{R}$.

- 
  - Write down the value of $d$.
  - Using the information given write down three equations involving $a$, $b$ and $c$.
  - Solve the system of equations to find the values of $a$, $b$ and $c$. [4]



From previous research, Coral knows that if a fish is flying for more than $1$ second then a seagull will attempt to catch it.

- Use a justification to explain why a seagull will attempt to catch this fish. [4]  

At $t=9\,$s a seagull begins swooping down to catch the fish.
Its height is given by $b(t)=-1.5t^2+27t-118$.

- 
  - Find the height at which the bird catches the fish.
  - Interpret the answer in the context of the problem. [4]

list.title: Question 37
list.content:
A team of painters is hired to paint a house. The time $T$ (in hours) required to paint the house varies inversely with the number of painters, $P$. This can be expressed as

$$
\begin{align*}
T &= \dfrac{k}{P}
\end{align*}
$$

A team of 3 painters can paint the house in 12 hours.

- Write an equation relating the time $T$ to the number of painters $P$.  [2]  

The following diagram shows the graph of $T=P$ for $0 \leq P \leq 12$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f6c0dfc-56fd-41ec-9a8d-73c9b11fe61f/images/5820e2f4-959d-4183-85b4-14415d66fc32/AI1177a.JPG)



- On the axes above, sketch the graph of $T(P)$ for $3 \leq P \leq 12$.[2]

- State the coordinates of the point of intersection.[1]

- State the meaning of the coordinates of this point in the context of the question. [1]

list.title: Question 38
list.content:
Consider the quadratic function $f(x) = ax^2+bx+c$. The graph of
$y=f(x)$ is shown in the diagram below. The vertex of the graph has
coordinates $\text{R}(m,-9)$.
The graph intersects the $x$-axis at two points; $\text{P}(-4,0)$ and
$\text{Q}(2,0)$.

- Find the values of $a$, $b$, and $c$.[5]

list.title: Question 39
list.content:
Certain content on the internet can become viral when the content
spreads exponentially. The spread of content published by a specific
content creator can be modelled by the function

$$
N(t)=145 \times 1.25^t,
$$

where $N$ is the number of people reached by
the content, and $t$ is the number of hours since the content's
publication.

- Write down the number of people reached immediately after the
content's publication.[1]

- Calculate the number of hours it takes for the content to reach
$100\hspace{0.15em}000$ people.[2]

- Calculate the number of people reached after $80$ hours.[2]


Approximately $5$ billion people in the world are now connected to the
internet.

- Explain why the model starts to become unrealistic after
about $3$ days.  [1]
list.markScheme:
- The immediate number of people reached can be found when $t=0$.
Hence,

  $$
  \answer{N(0)=145}
  $$

- We solve the equation

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(t) &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[4pt]
  145 \times 1.25^t &= 100\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[4pt]
  t &\answer{t\approx29.3}\hspace{3em} [\text{using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting $t=80$ into the function $N(t)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N(t) &= 145 \times 1.25^t \\[4pt]
  N(80) &= 145 \times 1.25^{80} \\[4pt]
  &= 8\hspace{0.15em}206\hspace{0.15em}709\hspace{0.15em}165.19 \\[4pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx8\hspace{0.15em}210\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.15em}000}\end{aligned}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{The model becomes unrealistic after about 3 days (72 hours) as the output of the model}}$
  $\answer{\text{(number of people reached) starts to exceed the total number of people in the world }}$
  $\answer{\text{connected to the internet.}}$

list.title: Question 40
list.content:
The graph below shows the profit $P$ (in thousands of dollars), that business A makes,  where $t$ is the time in months since January 1st.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d91ed14d-8746-4221-9d13-3870a93ffff5/images/c66ce31d-cb54-4bbd-848a-ef2cd4a05037/ai1106e.PNG)



- Write down one characteristic of the graph which suggests that a cubic function might be an appropriate model for the business profit. [1]  

The model can be expressed as $P(t)=at^3+bt^2+ct+d$, where $a$, $b$, $c$ and $d \in \mathbb{R}$. It is given that the graph of the model passes through the following points.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d91ed14d-8746-4221-9d13-3870a93ffff5/images/ef93a216-cfb9-450f-a315-71dbbb9af371/ai1106b.PNG)

If $P$ has a negative value, business A is losing money. The owner has decided they will not open during the corresponding time next year.

- Use the model from part (b) to find the approximate dates during which business A will not open next year. [4]  

Business B has a profit function given by $P(t)=-0.1t^2+1.2t$, for $0 \leq t \leq 12$.

- Determine the total amount of time for which business B is more profitable than business A. [3]

list.title: Question 41
list.content:
The amount of fuel in a car's tank, $V$, in litres, can be modelled by a
linear function, $V = mx + c$, where
$x$ is the distance driven measured in kilometres.
After driving $100$ km, the amount of fuel in
the tank is $33$ litres.

- Write down an equation that describes this information. [1]


After driving $250$ km, the amount of fuel in
the tank is $22.5$ litres.

- Write down an equation that describes this second piece of
information. [1]

- Calculate the amount of fuel in the tank after driving
$50$ km. [4]

list.title: Question 42
list.content:
The water depth, $D$, in metres, in a boating marina on a particular day
can be modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
D(t) &= 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24,\end{aligned}
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight.

- Write down the depth of water at midnight. [1]

- The cycle of water depths repeats every T hours. Find the value
of T. [2]

- 
  - Write down the minimum and maximum depths of water
during the day.
  - Find the times at which the minimum and maximum depths of water
occur during the day.[4]


- Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below.[3]

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13a225e5-63c6-476e-81ff-2ded39715f6e/images/9f9c68ce-1d0d-4487-a7d2-c9a33bc05e53/65ae508d3aaa92f2c9dd08b381c4298f16693fe9.svg)


- A ship with $8$ m draught is allowed to
enter the marina if the depth of water is greater than
$10$ m. Find the time interval before
midday, in hours and minutes, during which the ship is not
allowed to enter the marina. [4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{12.5\text{ m}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{T} &= \dfrac{360}{30} \hspace{0.1em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{=12}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The min and max values of the sine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max depths of water are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    D_{\text{min}} &=  4(-1)+12.5 \hspace{0.2em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 8.5\text{ m}} \\[15pt]
    D_{\text{max}} &=  4(+1)+12.5 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 16.5\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $D(t) = 8.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.9em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 8.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 9,\hspace{0.25em} 21 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the min depth of water occurs at
$\answer{9 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{9 \text{ pm}}$
    Similarly, solving the equation $D(t) = 16.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2.8em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 16.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 3,\hspace{0.25em} 15 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the max depth of water occurs at
$\answer{3 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{3 \text{ pm}}$

- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/13a225e5-63c6-476e-81ff-2ded39715f6e/images/3fbc1ff1-c2d9-4c80-a98e-ea0dfbdfbd10/51784b29690fe6ba6b16afe9863a1352814ae7c6.svg)


- Solving the equation $D(t) = 10$ for $t < 12$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.8em} 4\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + 12.5 &= 10 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 7.289,\hspace{0.25em} 10.711 \hspace{2.8em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.289(60) &= 17.34 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  0.711(60) &= 42.66\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the ship is not allowed to
enter the marina
$\answer{\text{between 7:17 am and 10:43 am}}$

list.title: Question 43
list.content:
The number of French words, $N$, that are remembered by students after
the completion of a French language course decreases exponentially over
time. This data can be modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
N(t) = a\times b^{-t} + 450,\end{aligned}
$$

where $a$ and $b$ are
positive constants, and $t$ is the time in years since a student
completed the French language course.
Immediately after completion, a student remembers $4200$ French words.

- Find the value of $a$. [2]


After $4$ years a student remembers only $1600$ French words.

- Find the value of $b$. [3]


The number of French words a student remembers never decreases below a
certain number of words, $n$.

- Write down the value of $n$.   [1]
list.markScheme:
- Solving the equation $N(0) = 4200$ for $a > 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\times b^{-0} + 450 &= 4200 \hspace{5.4em} \\[6pt]
  a + 450 &= 4200 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{a = 3750}
  $$

- Solving the equation $N(4) = 1600$ for $b > 0$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  3750\times b^{-4} + 450 &= 1600 \hspace{6.9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.6em} \answer{b \approx 1.34} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we draw the graph of $y = N(t)$, for $t \geq 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1aa30751-ed4b-44ac-bb07-63116dc7d37f/images/2a235dae-dec6-4e18-9719-39fb24c0f276/5f0266262d56defec1ffa52f191a9228b568fd3e.svg)


  Hence the value of $n$ is
$\answer{450}$

list.title: Question 44
list.content:
Mehmet organises a graduation party on a boat in the Strait of Istanbul
for his peers from college. The cost to rent a large boat for the
evening is $5000$ Turkish liras (TRY) and the cost to hire a DJ is
$1500$ TRY. The cost for food and drinks is estimated to be $125$ TRY
per person.

- Find an expression for the total cost, $y$ TRY, of the evening in
terms of the number of peers, $x$, attending the party. [2]

- Find the total cost of the evening if $40$ peers attend the party.
[2]

- Given that Mehmet decides to collect $250$ TRY from each peer
attending the party, find the least number of peers he has to invite
to be able to cover the total cost of the evening. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.8em} \text{Total cost} &= \text{Fixed costs} +  \text{Variable costs} \\[6pt]
  y &= (5000+1500) + 125x \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{y = 6500 + 125x} \hspace{1.2em}
  $$

- Evaluating $y = 6500 + 125x$ for $x = 40$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 6500 + 125(40) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 11\hspace{0.15em}500 \text{ TRY}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Total cost} &= 250x \hspace{9.2em} \\[6pt]
  6500 + 125x &= 250x \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{5.1em} \answer{x = 52} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 45
list.content:
The water depth, $D$, in metres, at the entrance of a boating harbour
can be modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
D(t) &= 4.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t + \ang{90}) + 15, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 24,\end{aligned}
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in hours, since midnight.

- Write down the depth of water at midnight. [1]

- The cycle of water depths repeats every T hours. Find the value
of T. [2]

- 
  - Write down the minimum and maximum depths of water
during the day.
  - Find the times at which the minimum and maximum depths of water
occur during the day.[4]


- Draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below.[3]

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5eb2e8d5-7054-4bdd-9c01-bd9a1fa5f2b9/images/2593030c-67cf-409b-9794-ba745de824ef/5ebec9fd250b988a5cdb00654083b4ecdda5ad72.svg)


- A ship with $10$ m draught is allowed to
enter the harbour if the depth of $\text{water}$ is greater
than $12$ m. Find the time interval
after midday, in hours and minutes, during which the ship is
not allowed to enter the harbour. [4]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{15\text{ m}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{T} &= \dfrac{360}{30} \hspace{0.1em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{=12}\end{aligned}
  $$

- 
  - The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max depths of water are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    D_{\text{min}} &=  4.5(-1)+15 \hspace{0.2em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 10.5\text{ m}} \\[15pt]
    D_{\text{max}} &=  4.5(+1)+15 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 19.5\text{ m}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $D(t) = 10.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.2em} 4.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t + \ang{90}) + 15 &= 10.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 3,\hspace{0.25em} 15 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the min depth of water occurs at
$\answer{3 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{3 \text{ pm}}$
    Similarly, solving the equation $D(t) = 19.5$ for $t$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.1em} 4.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t + \ang{90}) + 15 &= 19.5 \\[6pt]
    t &= 9,\hspace{0.25em} 21 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the max depth of water occurs at
$\answer{9 \text{ am}}$
and
$\answer{9 \text{ pm}}$

- If we draw the graph of $D$ versus $t$ on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5eb2e8d5-7054-4bdd-9c01-bd9a1fa5f2b9/images/26c8f477-b4fc-4200-831b-ec38467e5a08/86eb70569effce9a800c12036b0b3ecc63fb97b4.svg)


- Solving the equation $D(t) = 12$ for $t > 12$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.1em} 4.5\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t + \ang{90}) + 15 &= 12 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 13.394,\hspace{0.25em} 16.606 \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.394(60) &= 23.64 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  0.606(60) &= 36.36\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the ship is not allowed to

  enter the harbour
$\answer{\text{b\(/\)n 1:24 pm and 4:36 pm}}$

list.title: Question 46
list.content:
Two carpet cleaning companies have different pricing structures.
CarpetShine charges $1.80$ AUD per square metre, plus an upfront
scheduling fee of $50$ AUD. CleanMaster has no scheduling a service fee,
but the rate is $2.50$ AUD per square metre. Let $C_1(x)$ and $C_2(x)$

CarpetShine and CleanMaster respectively.

- Write down expressions for the costs, $C_1$ and $C_2$, of cleaning
$x$ square metres of carpet area. [2]

- Find the least number of whole square metres of carpet area cleaned
by $\text{CarpetShine}$ for its $\text{services}$ to
be a cheaper option. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{CarpetShine}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em} \answer{C_1(x) = 1.80x + 50} \hspace{0.6em} \qref{(1)}  \\[8pt]
  \text{CleanMaster}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em} \answer{C_2(x) = 2.50x} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graphs of $(1)$ and $(2)$, for $x \geq 0$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5fc2ff98-42dc-416f-a3a0-c7e1d46e3145/images/51d828e3-1f65-46c3-8c32-7a9992ed51a6/222304bb048f5e481f5e9f67da7635f92b5b303e.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(72\) whole square metres}}$
of carpet area is required for
  CarpetShine's cleaning services to be a cheaper option.

list.title: Question 47
list.content:
The mass of a radioactive sample is given by

$$
M(t)=P+Q\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^\frac{t}{300}, \qquad t\geq 0 \text{ days.}
$$

where t is the number of days after the sample was collected and
measured.
The initial weight of the sample is $20 \text{ g}$. When each atom emits
its $\alpha$-particle, the mass of the atom is reduced by $3.2\%$.

- 
  - Explain why P is the final mass of the sample after every atom
in the sample has emitted its $\alpha$-particle.
  - Hence, find the value of P, leaving your answer correct to two
decimal places. [2]


- Find the value of Q. [2]

- Estimate the mass of the sample after $2.5$ years (assume no leap
years). [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - We have

    $$
    M(t)=P+Q\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^\frac{t}{300}
    $$

    $\answer{{\text{As } t\rightarrow \infty, \left(\dfrac{1}{2} \right)^\frac{t}{300} \rightarrow 0. \text{ Therefore }, M(\infty) \approx P.}}$
  - Hence

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{2cm}P &= 0.968\times 20 \qquad [\text{$96.8\%$ of $20$}]\\[6pt]
    &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{ \approx 19.36 \text{ g}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- We have $M(0)=20$

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  M(0) &= P+Q\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^0\\[6pt]
  20 &= 19.36+Q\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-0.25cm}\answer{ Q = 0.64 }\end{aligned}
  $$

- $2.5$ years is $2.5\times 365 = 912.5 \text{ days}$. Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  M(912.5) &= 19.36+0.64\left(\dfrac{1}{2}\right)^{\frac{912.5}{300}}\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{0.35em}\answer{\approx 19.4  \text{ g}}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 48
list.content:
An oil tank at a mine site was at full capacity before the tank incurred
a puncture in the base and the oil start to leak out. A site engineer
used the following function, $L(t)$, to model the percentage of oil
remaining in the tank

$$
L(t)=100e^{-kt},\quad t\geq0,

$$

where $t$ is the
number of days after the puncture occurred.
The engineer found that after one day, $30\%$ of the oil originally in
the tank had leaked out.

- Find the value of $k$. [2]

- Use this model to find the percentage of oil remaining in the tank
after $30$ hours. [2]


Based on the model, the engineer makes the claim that the tank will
always have some oil in it and never completely empty.

- State a mathematical reason supporting the engineers claim.
[2]
list.markScheme:
- If $30\%$ oil has leaked, there is $70\%$ remaining in the tank. We
can substitute in $L=70$ and $t=1$ to find $k$, as follows

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L(t) &=100e^{-kt}\\[6pt]
  70 &=100e^{-k(1)}  \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.3em}\answer{\text{k}\approx0.357}  \hspace{2em} [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- $30$ hours is equal to $1.25$ days ($30/24=1.25$). Hence, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L(1.25) &= 100e^{-0.357(1.25)} \\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.5em}\answer{=64 \%}
  \end{aligned}
  $$

- We have $L(t)=100e^{-0.357t}$
  As $t\rightarrow \infty,\,\, L(t)\rightarrow 0$. Hence, there is a horizontal asymptote at $L=0$. The percentage of oil remaining gets very close to zero, but never reaches it.

list.title: Question 49
list.content:
Two IT consulting firms have different pricing structures. TechMind
charges $\$115$ per hour, plus an upfront fee of $\$250$ for booking an
appointment. RiddleBreak doesn't charge for booking an appointment, but
the rate is $\$160$ per hour. Let $C_1(t)$ and $C_2(t)$ be the costs, in
dollars, of consulting $t$ hours by TechMind and RiddleBreak
respectively.

- Write down expressions for the costs of consulting, $C_1$ and $C_2$,
in terms of the number of hours, $t$, charged. [2]

- Find the least number of whole hours of consulting from TechMind for
its $\text{services}$ to be a cheaper option. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{TechMind}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em} \answer{C_1(t) = 115t + 250} \hspace{0.6em} \qref{(1)}  \\[8pt]
  \text{RiddleBreak}:&\hspace{0.75em}\hspace{0.525em} \answer{C_2(t) = 160t} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graphs of $(1)$ and $(2)$, for $t \geq 0$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9ff19c56-9082-4058-a2cf-c84b25aad999/images/a990f43d-8499-4644-b38a-ba9bd26a4dc4/798f80d7abe42cc91e804962407e19461e89e38d.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(6\) whole hours}}$
is required for TechMind's consulting services
  to be a cheaper option.

list.title: Question 50
list.content:
The dietary reference intake (DRI, in grams), $y$, of protein for a
sedentary male adult of mass $x$ kg is
determined by the equation $y = mx + c$, where $m$ and $c$ are
constants.
For a male adult of mass $60$ kg the DRI of
protein is $69$ grams, and for a male adult of mass
$90$ kg the DRI of protein is $91.5$ grams.

- Determine the value of $m$ and the value of $c$. [3]

- Find the DRI of protein for a male adult of mass
$70$ kg. [2]

- Suggest a reason why the equation may not be appropriate for
determining the DRI of protein for a male child of mass
$40$ kg. [2]

list.title: Question 51
list.content:
The graph of a quadratic function has a $y$-intercept at A$(0,24)$ and
one of its $x$-intercepts is B$(2,0)$.
The $x$-coordinate of the vertex of the graph is $4$.
The equation of the quadratic function is in the form $y = ax^2+bx+c$.

- Write down the value of $c$. [1]

- Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4]

- Write down the coordinates of the second $x$-intercept of the
function. [1]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{c = 24}$
- Using the axis of symmetry formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{7.4em} 4 &= -\dfrac{b}{2a} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $x = 4$}] \\[6pt]
  b &= -8a \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the coordinates of B, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0 &= a(2)^2 + b(2) + c \\[6pt]
  [\text{from $(1)$ \& part (a)}] \hspace{2em} 0 &= a(2)^2 + (-8a)(2) + 24 \hspace{3.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{8.1em} \answer{a = 2} \\[3pt] \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

  Hence, substituting $a = 2$ in the equation $(1)$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  b &= -8(2) \hspace{0.4em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b = -16} \hspace{1.7em}
  $$

- $\answer{(6,0)}$

list.title: Question 52
list.content:
The following table shows the total revenue, $y$, in Australian dollars
(AUD), $\text{obtained}$ daily during the first week of January
$2020$, by Peppy's Pizza $\text{restaurant}$ and the number of
guests, $x$, served.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0b8e05a7-0c33-4aef-a8f9-eaa7da8cacbd/images/5c7e3e73-93f7-4332-8ef8-a9fee762c9a8/9736e8eb9c9cfe8a065bfa8f5344721e7887b704.svg)



- 
  - Calculate the Pearson's product-moment correlation coefficient,
$r$, for this data.
  - Hence comment on the result. [4]


- Write down the equation of the regression line $y$ on $x$.
[2]

- Use the line of the regression to estimate the revenue of serving
$70$ guests. Give your answer correct to the nearest AUD.
[3]


Daily maintenance cost for the restaurant is $240$ AUD. Additionally,
the cost of serving one guest is $5$ AUD.

- Determine if the restaurant makes a profit when serving
$45$ guests on a $\text{particular}$ day. [2]

- 
  - Write down an expression for the total revenue of serving $x$
guests.
  - Find an expression for the profit of the restaurant when serving
$x$ guests on a particular day.
  - Find the least number of guests required to be served to result
in a profit for the day. [5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{r = 0.991}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
  - $\answer{\text{Positive, strong correlation b/n the number of guests and revenue}}$

- $\answer{y = 10.4x - 14.3}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
- Evaluating $y = 10.4x - 14.3$ for $x = 70$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 10.4(70) - 14.3 \\[6pt] 
  &= 713.7 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 714 \text{ AUD}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The profit of the restaurant when serving $45$ guests on a
particular day is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
  &= 410 - (240 + 5(45)) \\[6pt]
  &= -55 \text{ AUD} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Hence the restaurant makes a loss when serving only \(45\) guests.}}$
- 
  - $\answer{\mathrm{Revenue} = 10.4x - 14.3}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.4em} \mathrm{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
    &= (10.4x - 14.3) - (240 + 5x) \\[6pt]
    &= 10.4x - 14.3 - 240 - 5x \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 5.4x - 254.3}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $\text{Profit} = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} 5.4x - 254.3 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &\approx 47.1 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(48\) guests}}$
are required to be served to result in a profit.

list.title: Question 53
list.content:
The following table shows the total revenue, $y$, in US dollars (USD),
$\text{obtained}$ monthly during the first six months of $2020$,
by Law Office of Fox Brothers and the number of clients, $x$, served.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3fada96d-f0c9-41f0-9d39-499c701ec1ba/images/c0269508-9618-4eab-8784-4661a19513ee/e4734e7152b428b88af8a05241306257c07d8464.svg)



- 
  - Calculate the Pearson's product-moment correlation coefficient,
$r$, for this data.
  - Hence comment on the result. [4]


- Write down the equation of the regression line $y$ on $x$.
[2]

- Use the line of the regression to estimate the revenue of serving
$20$ clients. Give your answer correct to the nearest USD.
[3]


Monthly operating cost for the law office is $\$2500$. Additionally, the
cost of serving each client is $\$200$.

- Determine if the law office makes a profit when serving $6$
clients on a $\text{particular}$ month. [2]

- 
  - Write down an expression for the total revenue of serving $x$
clients.
  - Find an expression for the profit of the law office when serving
$x$ clients on a particular month.
  - Find the least number of clients required to be served to result
in a profit for the month. [5]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - $\answer{r = 0.995}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
  - $\answer{\text{Positive, strong correlation b/n the number of clients and revenue}}$

- $\answer{y = 654x - 541}$ [$\text{by using G.D.C.}$]
- Evaluating $y = 654x - 541$ for $x = 20$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y &= 654(20) - 541 \hspace{0.5em} \\[6pt]
  &= 12\hspace{0.15em}539 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 12\hspace{0.15em}539} \end{aligned}
  $$

- The profit of the law office when serving $6$ clients on a
particular month is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.5em} \text{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
  &= 3000 - (2500 + 200(6)) \\[6pt]
  &= -\$700 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  $\answer{\text{Hence the law office makes a loss when serving only \(6\) clients.}}$
- 
  - $\answer{\mathrm{Revenue} = 654x - 541}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.3em} \mathrm{Profit} &= \text{Revenue} - \text{Costs} \\[6pt]
    &= (654x - 541) - (2500 + 200x) \\[6pt]
    &= 654x - 541 - 2500 - 200x \\[6pt]
    &\answer{= 454x - 3041}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Solving the equation $\text{Profit} = 0$ for $x$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.1em} 454x - 3041 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &\approx 6.70 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence
$\answer{\text{at least \(7\) clients}}$
are required to be served to result in a profit.

list.title: Question 54
list.content:
The brightness of a star can be measured in terms of its apparent magnitude, $M$, as seen from Earth.
The amount of energy received on Earth by a star is called the the observed flux density, $F$.
$M$ and $F$ are related by the following formula

$$
\frac{M}{2.5} = \log_{10}\left(\frac{1}{F}\right)
$$


- If a star has a value of $F=2500$, find the value of $M$.[2]

- Find $F$ as a function of $M$.[2]


The apparent magnitude of the sun is known to be $M_s=-26.8$ and the apparent magnitude of the full moon is known to be $M_m=-12.7$.

- Find their brightness factor, $\dfrac{F_s}{F_m}$, to three significant figures in the form $a\times10^k$, where $1<a<10$ and $k\in \mathbb{Z}$.  [3]

list.title: Question 55
list.content:
The data below shows the price, $y$, in Kazakhstani tenge (KZT), that
each bag of wheat flour can be purchased for at a wholesale market in
Almaty if $x$ bags are ordered.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/620f11cc-de36-420f-8fd5-6f61bec6fd2e/images/6fdb89eb-7ab4-4f60-a277-9ebc4bccb019/5a253ce60e250108cf649fd1f8dc000abcca0657.svg)



- Find an expression for the price, $y$ KZT, of each bag purchased in
terms of the number of bags, $x$, ordered. [2]

- Hence find the exact total cost of purchasing $250$ bags of wheat
flour. [3]
list.markScheme:
- From the data we see that $y$ is determined by the linear equation
$y= mx + c$.
  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  50m + c &= 6500  \qref{(1)} \\[6pt]
  100m + c &= 6000 \hspace{0.75em} \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Solving
the system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $m$ and $c$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  
  \hspace{8.9em} \begin{array}{rcl}
  m &=& -10 \\[6pt]
  c &=& 7000
  \end{array} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{y = -10x + 7000}$
- Evaluating $y = -10x + 7000$ for $x = 250$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.8em} y &= -10(250) + 7000 \\[6pt]
  &= 4500 \text{ KZT}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the total cost of
purchasing $250$ bags of wheat flour is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \text{Total cost} &= 4500(250) \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 1\hspace{0.15em}125\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ KZT}} \hspace{1em}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 56
list.content:
The average gasoline price, $P$, in cents per gallon, in USA $2019$ can
be modelled by the function

$$
\hspace{1em} P(t) = a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t+\ang{90}) + b, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 365,
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in days, since New Year's Eve $2018$.
Part of the graph of $y = P(t)$ is shown below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/80d14f42-a9e9-49a9-8f34-f3ad09b8c895/images/f323592f-678a-4312-aa48-55fd411bb4ce/eba99471e7227e6ca3549b0274fdd498563d4121.svg)



- Write down the value of $b$. [1]


The average price of gasoline at the end of $14$th of January, $2019$ was $328$
cents per gallon.

- Show that the value of $a$ is equal to 56. [2]

- Hence calculate:
  
  - the average gasoline price on the $14$th of February, $2019$;
  - the minimum and maximum average prices of gasoline in USA
$2019$. [3]



The cycle of average gasoline prices repeats every T days.

- Determine the value of T.[2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{300}$
- Solving the equation $P(14) = 328$ for $a$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 14+\ang{90}) + 300 &= 328 \hspace{10em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos \ang{300} + 300 &= 328 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.2em} \answer{a = 56} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 31+14 = 45$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P(45) &= 56\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{15}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 45+\ang{90}) + 300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 340 \text{ cents per gallon}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max average prices are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P_{\text{min}} &= 56(-1)+300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 244 \text{ cents per gallon}} \hspace{3em} \\[15pt]
    P_{\text{max}} &= 56(+1)+300 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 356 \text{ cents per gallon}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/80d14f42-a9e9-49a9-8f34-f3ad09b8c895/images/95fdb075-ae11-4e91-9c51-45fed90c3c09/0189e79cc182a1047199d3fb9dc1b367d698bb2d.svg)


  Hence we find
$\answer{\text{T} = 24}$

list.title: Question 57
list.content:
Part of the graph of $y = f(x)$ is shown below. The point A$(3,4)$ lies
on the graph.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bc997ee1-157a-4954-840a-c7cf3a649ca9/images/40752509-d462-43d8-b4eb-2c65b6d2b48f/cc26169f3e878b541f9e30065e66509e180ee603.svg)



- Write down the value of $f(3)$. [1]


The tangent line $L$ to the graph of $y = f(x)$ at point A has equation
$y = 3x - 5$.

- Find the equation of the normal line $N$ to the graph of
$y = f(x)$ at point A. Give your answer in the form
$ax + by + d = 0$, where $a, b, d \in \mathbb{Z}$. [3]

- Draw the lines $L$ and $N$ on the same grid above,
labelling the intercepts with the axes. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{f(3) = 4}$
- The gradient of $N$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.7em} m_{N} &= -\dfrac{1}{m_{L}} \hspace{3em} [\text{since $N \perp L$}] \\[6pt]
  &= -\dfrac{1}{3}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient
formula with A$(3,4)$ and $m = -1/3$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[5pt]
  y - 4 &= -\dfrac{1}{3}\hspace{0.05em}(x - 3) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{1.0em} 3(y - 4) &= -(x - 3) \\[11pt]
  3y - 12 &= -x + 3 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{x + 3y - 15 = 0} \hspace{4.65em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  L:&\hspace{1em} y = 3x - 5 \\[10pt] 
  \text{$x$-intercept}:& \hspace{1em} \mathrm{B}(5/3,0) \\[10pt]
  \text{$y$-intercept}:& \hspace{1em} \mathrm{C}(0,-5)\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  N:&\hspace{1em} y = -\dfrac{1}{3}x + 5 \\[6pt] 
  \text{$x$-intercept}:& \hspace{1em} \mathrm{D}(15,0) \\[10pt]
  \hspace{1.1em} \text{$y$-intercept}:& \hspace{1em} \mathrm{E}(0,5)\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we draw the lines $L$ and $N$ on the same grid below,
indicating the points B and E, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/bc997ee1-157a-4954-840a-c7cf3a649ca9/images/73281b15-cfe0-4b6f-854a-9bef91565be1/a6912eec889f05ce26fa48c17eb09f173f2604d9.svg)

list.title: Question 58
list.content:
The number of users on a new social network in $2018$ was
$320\hspace{0.15em}000$. One year later, in $2019$, the number of users
on this network is estimated to be $350\hspace{0.15em}000$. The number
of the users on this network, $N$, can be modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
N(t) = 320\hspace{0.15em}000\times b^t, \hspace{0.5em} t\geq0, \end{aligned}
$$

where $t$ is the number of years since $2018$ and $b$ is a constant.

- Find the value of $b$. [2]

- Estimate the number of the users on this network there will be in
$2023$.[2]

- Forecast the year for which the number of the social network users
reaches one million. Give your answer correct to the nearest
year. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c0462e85-e9f3-4564-b103-1800a0e6c31a/images/6fd93ccd-3403-459a-b1d0-cc108da6027c/033cf3beecde613f81a96d293306464dcb68241a.svg)


  Hence, solving the equation $N(1) = 350\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $b$,
we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  320\hspace{0.15em}000\times b &= 350\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{4.4em} \\[9pt]
  b &= \dfrac{350\hspace{0.15em}000}{320\hspace{0.15em}000} \\[6pt]
  b &= \dfrac{35}{32} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b \approx 1.09} \hspace{1.4em}
  $$

- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c0462e85-e9f3-4564-b103-1800a0e6c31a/images/84b094eb-d9dd-4085-b69d-76fef087f129/74c77aa092bfa1ac875f40785f7097708883e3e2.svg)


  Hence, evaluating $N(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.6em} N(5) &= 320\hspace{0.15em}000\times \left(\dfrac{35}{32}\right)^5 \\[4pt]
  &\approx 500\hspace{0.15em}888 \\[10pt]
  &\answer{\approx 501\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ users}}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Note: Using a rounded answer from part (a) will produce a different answer. It is very important to use unrounded answers in subsequent parts unless otherwise stated!
- Solving the equation $N(t) = 1\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.15em}000$
for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.75em} 320\hspace{0.15em}000\times \left(\dfrac{35}{32}\right)^t &= 1\hspace{0.15em}000\hspace{0.15em}000 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 12.7 \text{ years} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we determine the years corresponding to $t = 12$ and $t=13$, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c0462e85-e9f3-4564-b103-1800a0e6c31a/images/1245122b-6dac-4c68-8899-ca6456b3869e/a616f6ab254b62e363c8d49827ba23ea9d06f1c6.svg)


  Hence the number of network users reaches one million
$\answer{\text{during } 2030}$

list.title: Question 59
list.content:
A cannon-ball is fired from the top of a tower. The height, $h$, in
metres, of the cannon-ball above the ground is modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
h(t) = -2t^2 + 20t + 8, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0,\end{aligned}
$$

where
$t$ is the time, in seconds, since the moment the cannon-ball was fired.

- Write down the height of the tower. [1]

- Calculate the height of the cannon-ball $5$ seconds after it was
fired. [2]


The cannon-ball hits its target on the ground $n$ seconds after it was
fired.

- Find the value of $n$. [2]

- Find $h'(t)$. [2]

- Calculate the maximum height reached by the cannon-ball,
and
write down the corresponding time $t$. [3]

- Determine the total time the cannon ball was above the
height of the tower.[3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $h(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} h(0) &= -2(0)^2+20(0)+8 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $h(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.7em} h(5) &= -2(5)^2+20(5)+8 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 58 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $h(n) = 0$ for $n > 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2n^2+20n+8 &= 0 \hspace{9em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.2em} \answer{n \approx 10.4} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we differentiate $h(t)$ with respect to $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.2em} h'(t) &= \dfrac{\mathrm{d}}{\mathrm{d}t}\big[-2t^2+20t+8\big] \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= -4t+20}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = h(t)$, for $t \geq 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c760d599-f910-4557-b1f6-1de511fb6a68/images/1f252474-3408-41a9-a62f-a5254bf8ee4e/397bd75d8b517ae440b92c4aa69a8d23b9a43a67.svg)


  Hence the maximum height is
$\answer{58 \text{ m}}$
and it is reached after
$\answer{5 \text{ seconds}}$
- Solving the equation $h(t) = 8$ for $t > 0$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  -2t^2+20t+8 &= 8 \hspace{8.6em} \\[6pt]
  -2t^2+20t &= 0 \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{12.2em} \answer{t = 10 \text{ seconds}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 60
list.content:
At the start 2001, a team of zoologists introduced a new species of rabbit onto a large island. $1000$ rabbits were initially introduced and there were $1728$ rabbits at the start of 2004.
