The size of the population of the species, $N$, $t$ years after the start of 2001, can be modelled by the following function

$$
N(t) = p \times q^t, \quad \qquad t\geq 0
$$


- 
  - Show that the value of $p$ is $1000$.
  - Verify that $q=1.2$.[2]


- State the annual growth rate of the population as a percentage. [1]

- Use the model to predict the population size at the start of 2011.[2]


In 2012, the team observed that the growth rate of the rabbit species was changing and that the overall population was now in decline. Upon investigation, they found that the rabbits had became the prey of a new type of snake on the island. Zoologists adjusted their model to the following new function, where $t$ is still the number of years after the start of 2001.

$$
N(t) = 1380 \times (0.87)^{(t-12)} \quad \qquad t\geq 12
$$


- Use this model to find the size of the population at the start of 2019.[2]

- Find the year in which the population of the species will first drop below $200$.[3]

- In the period from 2013 onwards, find the number of complete years in which the size of the population of the species was greater than or equal to $800$.[3]


At the start of 2020, the remaining population of the species was transferred to another island along with $300$ more rabbits. The team of zoologists now expect the population growth will recover and will increase at a rate of $10\%$ per year.

- Estimate the size of the population at the start of 2030. [3]

list.title: Question 61
list.content:
The average petrol price, $P$, in cents per litre, in Australia $2019$
can be modelled by the function

$$
\hspace{1em} P(t) = a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{10}\hspace{-0.15em}\times t) + b, \hspace{0.5em} 0 \leq t \leq 365, \\[3pt]
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in days, since New Year's Eve $2018$.
Part of the graph of $y = P(t)$ is shown below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f4e9707a-58e9-43d3-a5cf-acd20baf6f9d/images/72a07772-6b2a-48cc-aea3-9d4440fb053e/3686d49d230056274ce98d6aa0d4dd1872a85c82.svg)



- Write down the value of $b$. [1]


The average price of petrol on the $21$st of January, $2019$ was $139$
cents per litre.

- Show the value of $a$ is equal to 12. [2]

- Hence calculate:
  
  - the average petrol price on the $10$th of February, $2019$;
  - the minimum and maximum average prices of petrol in Australia
$2019$.[3]



The cycle of average petrol prices repeats every T days.

- Determine the value of T.[2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{145}$
- Solving the equation $P(21) = 139$ for $a$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{10}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 21) + 145 &= 139 \hspace{7.4em} \\[6pt]
  a\sin 2\ang{10} + 145 &= 139 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.2em} \answer{a = 12} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 31+10 = 41$, we obtain

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P(41) &= 12\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{10}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 41) + 145 \hspace{1.8em} \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 154 \text{ cents per litre}}\end{aligned}
    $$

  - The min and max values of the sine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max average prices are

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    P_{\text{min}} &= 12(-1)+145 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 133 \text{ cents per litre}} \hspace{3em} \\[15pt]
    P_{\text{max}} &= 12(+1)+145 \\[6pt]
    &\answer{\approx 157 \text{ cents per litre}}\end{aligned}
    $$


- Using G.D.C., we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f4e9707a-58e9-43d3-a5cf-acd20baf6f9d/images/70f1d702-31c5-4aa3-bc1c-81a56736356c/30c06c40c5cf2c5d8e88197edf49a8900fddc76e.svg)


  Hence we find
$\answer{\text{T} = 36}$

list.title: Question 62
list.content:
Sarah's investment portfolio, $V(t)$, in Australian dollars (AUD), is
modelled by the function

$$
V(t) = 64\hspace{0.15em}000\times\left(1 + \dfrac{k}{100}\right)^t, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0,
$$

where $t$ is the number of years since $2019$ and $k$ is a constant.

- Find an expression for the value of the investment portfolio in
$2020$. Give your answer in the form $a + bk$, where
$a,b \in \mathbb{Z}^+$. [2]


Three years later, in $2022$, the value of the investment portfolio is
expected to be $74\hspace{0.15em}088$ AUD.

- Find the value of $k$. [2]


This model is defined for $0 \leq t \leq n$. At $n$ years, the value of
the investment portfolio would have doubled since $2019$.

- Find the value of $n$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff457177-5def-4306-a827-b5312983770c/images/6ecb8a65-c1f7-4db9-aa27-b8d368274747/70d7f3dfd5326294e23da6bf1d0710b2f53e7027.svg)


  Hence, substituting $t = 1$ in the expression for $V(t)$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} V(1) &= 64\hspace{0.15em}000\times\left(1 + \dfrac{k}{100}\right) \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 64\hspace{0.15em}000 + 640k}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $V(3) = 74\hspace{0.25em}088$ for $k$, we
obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  64\hspace{0.15em}000\times\left(1 + \dfrac{k}{100}\right)^3 &= 74\hspace{0.25em}088 \hspace{9.3em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{7.8em} \answer{k = 5} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $V(n) = 2\times64\hspace{0.15em}000$ for $n$,
we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  64\hspace{0.15em}000\times\left(1 + \dfrac{5}{100}\right)^n &= 128\hspace{0.15em}000 \hspace{9em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.6em} \answer{n \approx 14.2 \text{ years}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

list.title: Question 63
list.content:
A healthcare company is designing a new deodorant stick that can be modelled by the shape of a parabola as the top, vertical lines as the sides and a horizontal line as the base, on the $x$-axis. The parabola has end points at $(0,7)$ and $(5,7)$, and vertex at $(2.5,8)$.
This design is shown in the diagram below. All distances are measured in centimetres.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/0c28bf3a-d07a-4efc-8f72-f3bbd5583b2f/images/b0822073-b2c4-4e24-96eb-f3c9ee8d0169/AI1006a.PNG)


The quadratic curve can be expressed in the form $y=ax^2+bx+c$ for
$0\leq x \leq 5$.

- 
  - Find the value of $c$.
  - Using the points $(2.5,8)$ and $(5,7)$, write two equations in $a$ and $b$.
  - Hence, find the equation of the quadratic curve. [5]


- Find the area of the shaded region in the deodorant
design.[3]

list.title: Question 64
list.content:
Gordon is cooking steaks for his friends Gino and Fred. When Gordon removes the first steak from the grill, the rate at which the internal temperature decreases can be modelled by the function:

$$
\begin{align*}
T_1 (t)=ke^{-0.0811t}+20
\end{align*}
$$

Where $T_1$ is the temperature of the steak in $^\circ \mathrm{C}$, $t$ minutes after it has been removed from the grill. $k$ is a positive constant.
At the time the first steak is removed from the grill, it has an internal temperature of $65^\circ \mathrm{C}$.

- Find the value of $k$.[2]

- State the equation of the horizontal asymptote of the graph of $y=T_1(t)$. Interpret this in context. [2]


Gordon wants to let the steak rest until it reaches an internal temperature of $50^\circ \mathrm{C}$.

- Calculate the length of time the steak should rest for.[2]  

At the exact time Gordon removes the first steak from the grill, he adds two more steaks to the grill to cook. The rate at which the internal temperature of the steaks increases on the grill can be modelled by the function:

$$
\begin{align*}
T_2 (t)=180-160e^{-0.0472t}
\end{align*}
$$

Where $T_2$ is the temperature of the steaks in $^\circ \mathrm{C}$, $t$ minutes after they have been placed on the grill.

- State the equation of the horizontal asymptote of the graph of $y=T_2(t)$. Interpret this in context.	 [2]

- Determine the time at which all three steaks have the same internal temperature. [3]


Gino wants his steak rare, and so Gordon removes it from the grill after $6.5$ minutes.

- Calculate the internal temperature of Ginos steak when it is taken off the grill. [2]  

Fred wants his steak well done, which means an internal temperature of $75^\circ \mathrm{C}$.

- Calculate how much longer Freds steak will stay on the grill after Ginos is removed.[3]

list.title: Question 65
list.content:
The graph shows the curve of a quadratic function of the form
$f(x) = ax^2 + bx + 90$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6886819b-3fbd-43d3-95f6-61cf97d171c1/images/abf35098-dbcc-4ba6-a3af-f17c013fd694/e02d6931ce58420fa7c9cbe422473aefce55e151.svg)



- Write down the equation for the axis of symmetry of the curve.
[2]

- Hence, or otherwise, find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$.
[3]

- Find the $y$-coordinate of the vertex of the curve. [1]
list.markScheme:
- The axis of symmetry intersects the $x$-axis midway between the
$x$-intercepts.
  Hence we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.15em} x &= \dfrac{-5+9}{2} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.4em} \answer{x = 2}
  $$

- Using the coordinates of A, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(-5) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  a(-5)^2 + b(-5) + 90 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  25a - 5b &= -90 \hspace{1em} \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using the
coordinates of B, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(9) &= 0 \\[6pt]
  \hspace{0.6em} a(9)^2 + b(9) + 90 &= 0 \\[6pt]
  81a + 9b &= -90 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the system
of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.4em} \answer{a = -2}\hspace{0.75em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.75em}\answer{b = 8}\hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- The vertex of the curve lies on the axis of symmetry.
Hence, evaluating $f(x)$ for $x = 2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.8em} f(2) &= -2(2)^2 + 8(2) + 90 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 98}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 66
list.content:
A farmer is going to fence two equal adjacent parcels of land. These
parcels share one side (which also requires fencing) as shown in the
following diagram. The farmer has only $80$ metres of fence.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/942728b4-5d3b-49b2-b0df-1f2bcfdbdfa5/images/942ca9e0-fea9-4897-abd7-6e372c3eaafb/580f23d360211ad7dd2c45e79d30c7d9c7d24f56.svg)



- Write down the equation for the total length of the fence,
$80\,$m, in terms of $x$ and $y$.
[1]

- Write down the total area of both parcels of land in terms of $x$.
[2]

- Find the maximum area, in m$^2$, of one parcel of land. [3]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{80 = 3x + 4y}$
- The total area of both parcels of land in terms of $x$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} A(x) &= x(2y) \\[18pt]
  &= 2xy \\[11pt]
  &= 2x\left(\dfrac{80 - 3x}{4}\right) \hspace{3em} [\text{from part (a)}] \\[7pt]
  &\answer{= 40x - \dfrac{3}{2}x^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = A(x)$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/942728b4-5d3b-49b2-b0df-1f2bcfdbdfa5/images/c56e4bf6-38aa-4ad7-9220-a283e89a5d6e/d34855549a850484b1041b3153951956e33882fa.svg)


  Hence the maximum area of one parcel of land is
$\dfrac{266.67}{2} \approx$
$\answer{133 \text{ m}^2}$

list.title: Question 67
list.content:
The downward speed, $V$, in metres per second, gained by a skydiver
during a jump is modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
V(t) = 56 - 56\times3^{-\frac{t}{4}}, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0,\end{aligned}
$$

where $t$, in seconds, is the time for which the skydiver is free
falling in the air.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/c78843c2-7d92-4862-b0e4-d8852e751513/images/0c7e427a-797f-41b5-a346-4d216bf8de4c/d3ee9eadbfc138be37002b3f29e50508f36ba8d9.svg)



- Write down the downward speed of the skydiver at $t=0$. [1]


The line $L$ is the horizontal asymptote to the graph.

- Determine the equation of $L$. [2]


The skydiver starts to feel no acceleration when he reaches the speed of
$55$ metres per second.

- Find the time it takes for the skydiver to reach this
speed. Give your answer correct to the nearest second.
  [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $V(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} V(0) &= 56-56\times 3^0 \\[6pt]
  &= 56-56 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 0 \text{ m$/$s}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.2em} \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} V(t) &= \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} \big[56 - 56\times3^{-\frac{t}{4}}\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 56 - 0 \hspace{2em} [\text{since $3^{-\frac{t}{4}} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$}] \\[10pt]
  &= 56 \text{ m$/$s}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the equation of $L$ is
$\answer{y = 56}$
- Solving the equation $V(t) = 55$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3.5em} 56 - 56\times3^{-\frac{t}{4}} &= 55 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 14.7 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it takes
$\answer{15 \text{ seconds}}$
to reach the speed of $55$ metres per second.

list.title: Question 68
list.content:
A population of goldfish decreases exponentially. The size of the
population, $P$, after $t$ days is modelled by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
P(t) = 8000\times2^{-t} + 100, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0. \\
\end{aligned}
$$


- Write down the exact size of the initial population. [1]

- Find the size of the population after $5$ days. [2]

- Calculate the time it will take for the size of the population to
decrease to $120$.[2]


The population will stabilize when it reaches a size of $n$.

- Write down the value of $n$.   [1]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 0$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4.7em} P(0) &= 8000\times2^0 + 100 \\[6pt]
  &= 8000 + 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 8100}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $P(t)$ for $t = 5$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.3em} P(5) &= 8000\times2^{-5} + 100 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 350}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $P(t) = 120$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  8000\times2^{-t} + 100 &= 120 \hspace{6.1em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{14.2em} \answer{t = 8.64 \text{ days}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.9em} \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} P(t) &= \lim_{t\rightarrow\infty} \big[8000\times2^{-t} + 100\big] \\[6pt]
  &= 0+100 \hspace{2em} [\text{since $2^{-t} \rightarrow 0$ as $t \rightarrow \infty$}] \\[10pt]
  &= 100 \text{ days}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the value of $n$ is
$\answer{100}$

list.title: Question 69
list.content:
The decibel scale measures how loud a sound is to the human ear. The decibel rating, $\mathrm{dB}$, of a sound can be modelled as a function of its sound intensity, $I$, as shown by the equation

$$
\begin{align*}
    \mathrm{dB} = 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120
\end{align*}
$$

Where $I$ is measured in Watts per square metre $(\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2)$ and $I>0$.
The pain threshold for the average human ear is $130\,\mathrm{dB}$.

- Show that the pain threshold is reached at exactly $10\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$.   [1]  

Amelia has a diesel generator that has a sound intensity of $1 \times 10^{-3.5}\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$.

- Determine the decibel rating of Amelia's generator. [2]  

Amelia is considering replacing her old diesel generator and has discovered a quieter petrol generator that has a decibel rating of $50\,\mathrm{dB}$.

- Determine the sound intensity of the petrol generator. Give your answer in the form $a \times 10^k$ where $1 \leq a < 10$ and $k \in \mathbb{Z}$.[2]

- Find how many times greater the sound intensity of the diesel generator is compared to the petrol generator.[2]
list.markScheme:
- Substituting $I=10$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,10 + 120 = 130
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The pain threshold of $130\,\mathrm{dB}$ is reached at a sound intensity of exactly $10\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$.
- Substituting $I=1 \times 10^{-3.5}$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{dB} &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,\left(1 \times 10^{-3.5}\right) + 120 \\[8pt]
  &= 85
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{Amelia's generator has a rating of $85\,\mathrm{dB}$.}}$
- Substituting $\mathrm{dB}=50$ into our equation, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  50 &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120
  \end{align*}
  $$

  And we know that $0<I<10^{-3.5}$. Using the numeric solver on the G.D.C. we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \mathrm{nSolve}\big(50 &= 10\,\mathrm{log}_{10}\,I + 120\,,I\,\big)\,|\,0<I<10^{-3.5} \\[8pt]
  I &= 0.0000001
  \end{align*}
  $$

  $\tcbhighmath{\text{The sound intensity of the petrol generator is $1 \times 10^{-7}\,\mathrm{W}/\mathrm{m}^2$.}}$
- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \dfrac{1 \times 10^{-3.5}}{1 \times 10^{-7}} \approx 3162
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The sound intensity of the diesel generator is approximately 3160 times greater than the sound intensity of the petrol generator.

list.title: Question 70
list.content:
A hot apple pie was taken out of the oven and left cooling on the bench.
The $\text{temperature}$ of the kitchen is
$19$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$. This situation can
be modelled by the exponential function $T = a + b\big(k^{-t}\big)$,
where $T$ is the temperature of the $\text{apple}$ pie, in
$\text{\textdegree{C}}$, and $t$ is the number of minutes for which the
apple pie has been on the bench in the kitchen. A sketch of the
situation is given below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1a60d715-c424-44cb-8944-85a330b2888c/images/7e03cf5a-bd9f-4377-9abc-d311967031fb/8b700a3ae9a0f49f95d8ab1106661a5c84fe1ddf.svg)



- Explain why $a = 19$. [2]


Initially, at $t = 0$, the temperature of the apple pie is
$180$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$.

- Find the value of $b$. [2]


After being left cooling on the bench for one minute, the temperature of
the apple pie is $159$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$.

- Show that $k = 1.15$. [2]

- Find the temperature of the apple pie five minutes after it
has been left cooling on the bench. [2]

- Find the total time needed for the apple pie to reach a
temperature of $30$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$.
Give your answer in minutes and seconds, correct to the nearest
second. [3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1a60d715-c424-44cb-8944-85a330b2888c/images/b39e9049-ef3b-49ee-833b-90b8d18f7d54/1fd4fa4206d204d02ea08ff6cea05417465e9ca9.svg)


  On the other hand, we know the temperature of the apple pie cannot
fall below the temperature of the kitchen.
  Hence we must have $a = 19$.
- When $t = 0$, we have $T = 180$.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  19 + b\big(k^{0}\big) &= 180 \hspace{3.3em} \\[6pt]
  19 + b &= 180 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.5em} \answer{b = 161} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- When $t = 1$, we have $T = 159$.
Hence we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  19 + 161\big(k^{-1}\big) &= 159 \hspace{5em} \\[6pt]
  19 +  \dfrac{161}{k} &= 159 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{11.65em} \answer{k = 1.15} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Evaluating $T = 19 + 161\big(1.15^{-t}\big)$ for $t = 5$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} T &= 19 + 161\big(1.15^{-t}\big) \\[6pt]
  &= 19 + 161\big(1.15^{-5}\big) \\[7pt]
  &\answer{\approx 99.0 \text{\hspace{0.15em}\textdegree{C}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T = 30$ for $t$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.4em} 19 + 161\big(1.15^{-t}\big) &= 30 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 19.2006 \text{ min} \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \hspace{1.6em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{13.75em} \answer{t \approx 19 \text{ min} + 12 \text{ sec}} \hspace{2.5em} [(0.2006)(60) \approx 12.0]
  $$

list.title: Question 71
list.content:
An archer shoots an arrow at a circular target in front of her.
The trajectory of the arrow is perpendicular to the circular target which is $x$ metres away.
The height, in metres, of the arrows above the ground is found by the formula:

$$
h = 0.015x+1.55
$$


- Find the height the arrow reaches when the target is $70$ meters away. [1]

  The centre of the target is at a height of $2.45\hspace{0.15em}$m above the ground.
  Hitting the inner circle of radius $12\,$cm scores $10$ points. The next circle has a radius of $22\,$cm and scores $8$ points. The final circle has a radius of $32\,$cm and scores $6$ points.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5808a386-ece2-424c-90ce-4d566c437d9c/images/7482106f-495f-482d-afe1-a3d0c43f39f3/q1126.png)


- Find the score obtained by the shot. [2]


The second shot is influenced by air resistance and the equation describing the height is now given by

$$
h_2 = -0.001x^2 + 0.0791x + 1.55
$$


- Find the score obtained by the second shot. [2]

- Calculate the maximum height reached by $h_2$. [1]
list.markScheme:
- By evaluating the formula at $x=70$, we have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h &= 0.015(70)+1.55 \\[9pt]
  &\hspace{0.275em}\tcbhighmath{= 2.6 \text{ m}} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- The height above the centre of the target is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  d &= 2.6-2.45 \\[8pt]
  &= 15\text{ cm} \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The arrow is within the second circle of radius $22\,$cm.
  The arrow scores $\answer{8}$.

  $$
      \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$


$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- Evaluating $h_2$ at $x=70$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  h_2 &= -0.001(70)^2 + 0.0791(70)) + 1.55 \\[8pt]
  &= 2.187...
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Hence, the distance to the centre of the target is

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  d_2 &= |2.187...-2.45| \\[8pt]
  &= 0.263...\tag*{\textbf{A1}}\\
  &= 26\hspace{0.15em}\text{cm}
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The arrow is within the third circle of radius $32\,$cm.
  The arrow scores $\tcbhighmath{6}$

  $$
      \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$


$\textcolor{white}{gap}$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = h_2(x)$, for $x \geq 0$ [by using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5808a386-ece2-424c-90ce-4d566c437d9c/images/1e39b79f-8205-4009-b8c4-b21d0dde44af/a1126.png)


  Hence the maximum height is $\answer{3.11 \text{ m}}$

  $$
  \tag*{\textbf{A1}}
  $$

list.title: Question 72
list.content:
A set of BMX jumping ramps have been constructed at a local cycle park, as shown in the following diagram. It is designed for riders to take off from the first ramp, represented by $f(x)$, and land on the second ramp, represented by $g(x)$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/6e6fba44-ae40-4292-a287-5720870a3e3e/images/72e41c7b-2eb3-46ea-a3bd-57ec52baf40b/1197a.JPG)


$\hspace{2em}\bullet$ The first ramp starts at the origin and ends at point $A$, and has equation $f(x)=\dfrac{1}{3} x^2 \text{ for } 0\leq x \leq 3$.
$\hspace{2em}\bullet$ The second ramp starts at point $C$ and ends at point $E$, and has equation $g(x)=\dfrac{1}{3} x^2-8x+48 \text{ for } 9\leq x \leq 12$.
$\hspace{2em}\bullet$ $p(x)$ represents the path a rider would take in the air between the ramps between point $A$ and point $C$.
$\hspace{2em}\bullet$ $q(x)$ represents a safety net that hangs between point $A$ and point $C$, and has equation $q(x)=\dfrac{1}{9} x^2-\dfrac{4}{3} x+6 \text{ for } 3\leq x \leq 9$.
$\hspace{2em}\bullet$ Point $A$ has coordinates (3,3) and point $C$ has coordinates (9,3).
It is given that all units and measurements are in metres.
The path of a rider at point $A$ is the tangent to $f(x)$ at that point.

- 
  - Determine the gradient of $f(x)$ at point $A$.
  - Hence, determine the equation of the path of a rider at point $A$. Give your answer in the form $y=mx+c$.[4]



The line $BC$ represents a support beam and is a normal to $g(x)$ at point $C$.

- 
  - Determine the gradient of $g(x)$ at point $C$.
  - Hence, determine the equation of the line representing the support beam $BC$.[6]



$p(x)$ is a parabola with a maximum at (6,6).

- Determine the equation of $p(x)$.  [2]  

A safety regulation at the cycle park is that a BMX rider using the jumping ramps should never be more than 5 metres above the safety net while in the air.

- Determine whether the model predicts that this safety regulation will be upheld.	[4]

list.title: Question 73
list.content:
A loaf pan is made in the shape of a cylinder. The pan has a diameter of
$24$ cm and a height of
$5$ cm.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9aaafe79-56c4-4a37-b409-43676a3d5eed/images/855b65c5-7644-44f9-a953-a91912965eb3/a347288bee589088e6dce052611dad40b73c72e7.svg)



- Calculate the volume of this pan. [3]


Gloria prepares enough bread dough to exactly fill the pan. The dough
was in the shape of a sphere.

- Find the radius of the sphere in cm, correct to one decimal
place. [4]


The bread was cooked in a hot oven. Once taken out of the oven, the
bread was left in the kitchen.
The temperature, $T$, of the bread, in degrees
Celsius, $\text{\textdegree{C}}$, can be
modelled by the function

$$
T(t) = a\times(1.51)^{-\frac{t}{3}} + 21, \hspace{0.5em} t \geq 0,
$$

where $a$ is a constant and $t$ is the time, in minutes, since the bread
was taken out of the oven.
When the bread was taken out of the oven its temperature was
$205$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$.

- Find the value of $a$. [2]

- Find the temperature that the bread will be $10$ minutes
after it is taken out of the oven. [2]


The bread can be eaten once its temperature drops to
$35$ $\text{\textdegree{C}}$.

- Calculate, to the nearest minute, the time since the bread
was taken out
of the oven until it can be eaten. [3]

- In the context of this model, state what the value of $21$
represents. [1]
list.markScheme:
- Using the volume of a cylinder formula with $r = 12$ and $h = 5$, we
get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.05em} V_{\text{pan}} &= \pi r^2h \\[6pt]
  &= \pi(12)^2(5) \\[6pt]
  &= 720\pi \qref{(1)}  \\[6pt]
  &=2261.9...\\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 2260 \text{ cm}^3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using the volume of a sphere formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{5.4em} V_{\text{dough}} &= V_{\text{pan}} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3 &= 720\pi \hspace{3em} [\text{from  $(1)$}] \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the equation $(2)$ for $r$, we obtain

  $$
  \hspace{12.9em} \answer{r \approx 8.1 \text{ cm}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(0) = 205$ for $a$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  a\times(1.51)^0 + 21 &= 205 \hspace{5.65em} \\[6pt]
  a + 21 &= 205 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.8em} \answer{a = 184}
  $$

- Evaluating $T(t)$ for $t=10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{4em} T(10) &= 184\times(1.51)^{-\frac{10}{3}} + 21 \\[9pt]
  &\answer{\approx 67.6 \text{\hspace{0.15em}\textdegree{C}}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(t) = 35$ for $t$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{1.6em} 184\times(1.51)^{-\frac{t}{3}} + 21 &= 35 \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 18.8 \hspace{3.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}] \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{1.8em} \answer{t \approx 19 \text{ minutes}}
  $$

- $\answer{\text{\(21\) is the room  temperature of the kitchen}}$

list.title: Question 74
list.content:
A factory produces bars in the shape of a cuboid, with a fixed height of
$30$ cm and varying base. The area, $A$, of each
bar base is described by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
A(x) &= x(40 - x), \hspace{0.5em} 5 \leq x \leq 35,\end{aligned}
$$

where
$x$ is the length of the bar base in centimetres.

- Bar P has a length of $10$ cm. Find the
volume of P. [2]

- Bar Q has the same volume as bar P, however has a different length.
Find the length of Q. [2]

- Find the value of $x$ that makes the bar's volume a maximum, and
state this maximum volume. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The volume of a bar with base length $x$ cm
is given by the function

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.95em} V(x) &= A(x)\times h \\[7pt]
  &= x(40-x)(30) \\[6pt]
  &= 1200x - 30x^2 \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, evaluating $V(x)$ for
$x = 10$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.85em} V(10) &= 1200(10) - 30(10)^2 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 9000 \text{ cm}^3}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $V(x) = 9000$ for $x \neq 10$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  1200x - 30x^2 &= 9000 \hspace{6.7em} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{9.85em} \answer{x = 30 \text{ cm}} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = V(x)$, for $5 \leq x \leq 35$ [by
using G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a4b969d0-4df7-4184-8874-c1e566eb036b/images/590e9d59-33f3-47b2-8b53-31174f419f04/862b3de66152091d457aa4678f6ddd98efb4d6c4.svg)


  Hence the maximum volume is
$\answer{12\hspace{0.15em}000 \text{ cm}^3}$
and it occurs when
$\answer{x = 20 \text{ cm}}$

list.title: Question 75
list.content:
The half-life, $T$, in years, of a radioactive isotope can be modelled
by the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
T(k) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{k}{100}\right)}, \hspace{0.5em} 0 < k < 100,\end{aligned}
$$

where $k$ is the decay rate, in percent, per year of the isotope.

- The decay rate of Hydrogen-$3$ is $5.5$ %
per year. Find its half-life.[2]


The half-life of Uranium-$232$ (U-$232$) is $68.9$ years. A sample
containing $250$ grams of U-$232$ is obtained and stored as a side
product of a nuclear fuel cycle.

- Find the decay rate per year of U-$232$. [2]

- Find the amount of U-$232$ left in the sample after:
  
  - $68.9$ years;
  - $100$ years. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(k)$ for $k = 5.5$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  T(5.5) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{5.5}{100}\right)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 12.3 \text{ years}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(k) = 68.9$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{r}{100}\right)} &= 68.9 \hspace{6.05em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.3em} \answer{k = 1.00\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{125 \text{ grams}}$
  - We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 250$ and
the $\text{common}$ ratio $r = (1 - 1.00/100) = 0.99$.
    Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n=101$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    u_{101} &= u_1r^{101-1} \\[6pt]
    &= 250\hspace{0.05em}(0.99)^{101-1} \hspace{0.2em} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 91.5 \text{ grams}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 76
list.content:
In a water filtration plant, the containers of water are filled and then
filtered, all by an automated system. The volume of water in a
container, $W(t)$, in litres, after $t$ seconds of the filling
commencing can be modelled by the function

$$
W(t) = V(1-e^{\frac{-t}{k}}),
$$

where $V$ is the maximum volume of the
water container and $k$ is a positive constant used to alter the rate at
which water is filling the containers.
The value of $k$ is currently set at 25.

- Find how long it takes, $t$, for a container to fill up to $50\%$ of
its maximum volume. [2]

- If one of the containers has a maximum volume of 20 litres, find the
volume of water in this container after $22$ seconds. [2]


The engineers of the plant want to alter the value of $k$ so that it
takes $20$ seconds to fill each container up to $95\%$ of their maximum
volumes.

- Find the value of $k$ required.   [2]
list.markScheme:
- Since the container is $50\%$ of its maximum volume,
$W=\dfrac{V}{2}$. Hence

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{V}{2}&=V(1-e^{\frac{-t}{25}})\\[6pt]
  \dfrac{1}{2}&=1-e^{\frac{-t}{25}}\\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\answer{t\approx17.3 \text{ seconds}} \qquad \qquad \qquad [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Substituting $V=20$ and $t=22$ into $W(t)$ function, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  W(t) &= V(1-e^{\frac{-t}{25}})\\[6pt]
  W(22)  &=20(1-e^{\frac{-22}{25}})\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.5em}\answer{\approx11.7 \text{ litres}} \qquad \qquad \qquad [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Since the containers are filled to $95\%$ of their maximum volume,
$W=0.95V$. Hence,

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  0.95V&=V(1-e^{\frac{-20}{k}})\\[6pt]
  0.95&=1-e^{\frac{-20}{k}}\\[6pt]
  e^{\frac{-20}{k}}&=0.05\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{-0.5em}\answer{k\approx 6.68} \qquad \qquad \qquad [\text{using GDC}]\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 77
list.content:
The half-life, $T$, in days, of a radioactive isotope can be modelled by
the function

$$
\begin{aligned}
T(k) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{k}{100}\right)}, \hspace{0.5em} 0 < k < 100,\end{aligned}
$$

where $k$ is the decay rate, in percent, per day of the isotope.

- The decay rate of Gold-$196$ is $6.2$ % per
day. Find its half-life.[2]


The half-life of Phosphorus-$32$ (P-$32$) is $14.3$ days. A sample
containing $120$ grams of P-$32$ is produced and stored in a
biochemistry laboratory.

- Find the decay rate per day of P-$32$. [2]

- Find the amount of P-$32$ left in the sample after:
  
  - $14.3$ days;
  - $50$ days. [3]
list.markScheme:
- Evaluating $T(k)$ for $k = 6.2$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  T(6.2) &= \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{6.2}{100}\right)} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 10.8 \text{ days}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $T(k) = 14.3$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \dfrac{\ln 0.5}{\ln\left(1 - \frac{r}{100}\right)} &= 14.3 \hspace{6.05em} \\ \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{10.25em} \answer{k = 4.73\hspace{0.05em}\%} \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]
  $$

- 
  - $\answer{60 \text{ grams}}$
  - We have a geometric sequence with the first term $u_1 = 120$ and
the $\text{common}$ ratio $r = (1 - 4.73/100) = 0.9527$.
    Hence, using the $n$th term formula $u_n = u_1r^{n-1}$ with
$n=51$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{0.8em} u_{51} &= u_1r^{51-1} \\[6pt]
    &= 120\hspace{0.05em}(0.9527)^{51-1} \\[7pt]
    &\answer{\approx 10.6 \text{ grams}}\end{aligned}
    $$

list.title: Question 78
list.content:
The Burj Khalifa, located in Dubai, is the tallest building in the
world. It has a height of $830 \text{ m}$ and has a square base that
covers a floor area of $556 \text{ m} \times 556 \text{ m}$. A tourism
shop located near the building sells souvenirs of the tower, which sit
inside glass pyramids, as illustrated by the diagram below. The souvenir
tower is an accurate scale replica of the actual tower.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/490aa73b-d0b9-484e-9cf9-6362beb9193f/75dbfe1df45464ae26235a84b47e84fedd3f43ea.svg)


The scaled model of Burj Khalifa has a base area of
$20 \text{ cm} \times 20 \text{ cm}$. The height and base area
dimensions of the glass pyramid are 10% larger than the model.

- 
  - Find the height of the souvenir tower, in cm, correct to the
nearest mm.
  - Find the volume of the glass pyramid, rounding your answer
correct to the nearest cubic centimetre. [5]



The shop owner aims to maximise profits from selling the souvenirs. The
more the owner orders from the manufacturer, the cheaper the souvenirs
are to buy. However, if too many are ordered, profits may decrease due
to surplus stock unsold.
The number of souvenirs ordered from previous years and the resulting
profits are shown in the following table.
QuantityProfit($)$5000$$35\,000$$10\,000$$95\,500$$13\,000$$116\,500$
The shop owner decides to fit a cubic model of the form

$$
P(x) = ax^3+bx^2+cx+d
$$

to model the profit, $P$, for $x$ thousand
souvenirs ordered.

- Explain why $d=0$.[1]

- Construct three linear equations to solve for $a$, $b$ and $c$, and
hence write down the completed function $P(x)$. [5]

- Find $P'(x)$.[2]

- Find, to the nearest hundred souvenirs, the optimal number of
souvenirs the owner should buy to maximise profit, and the resulting
profit from this number. [4]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - The height $(h_m)$ of the model can be calculated by

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    h_m&= \text{height of Burj Khalifa} \times \text{scale factor}\\[6pt]
    &= 83000 \times \dfrac{20}{55600}\hspace{4.1em} [\text{all values in cm}] \\[6pt]
    &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx 29.9 \text{ cm} }\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Let $x$ be the side length of the base and $h$ be the height of
the glass pyramid. Since the dimensions of glass pyramid are
$10\%$ larger than the model, we get

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    x&= 20+20(0.1)\hspace{2cm} \\[6pt]
    &= 22 \text{ cm}\\[6pt]
    h&= 29.9+29.9(0.1)\\[6pt]
    &\approx 32.9 \text{ cm}\end{aligned}
    $$


  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/19611668-b3b5-4172-ace2-b6f0010e0b75/c16aa6b415e3ff65a129bf040b3ec43c108d55ec.svg)


  The volume $(V)$ of the glass pyramid can therefore be calculated by

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V&= \dfrac{1}{3}\times x^2 \times h \\[6pt]
  &=\dfrac{1}{3}\times (22)^2 \times(32.9)\\[6pt]
  &\hspace{0.3em}\answer{\approx 5308 \text{ cm}^3 }\end{aligned}
  $$

- If zero souvenirs are ordered (i.e. $x=0$), there won't be any
souvenirs to sell. Hence, the profit, $P$, will also be zero.

  $$
  \answer{P(0)=0, \,\text{ hence } \, d=0 }
  $$

- Since $x$ is in thousands, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  P(5)&=5^3a+5^2b+5c=35\, 000\qref{(1)}\\[6pt]
  P(10) &= 10^3a+10^2b+10c = 95\, 500\qref{(2)}\\[6pt]
  P(13) &= 13^3a+13^2b+13c = 116\, 500 \qref{(3)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Using
G.D.C. to solve the equations $(1)$, $(2)$ and $(3)$, we get

  $$
  a=-\dfrac{2295}{26},\, b=\dfrac{47685}{26}, \text{ and } c=\dfrac{475}{13}
  $$

  Hence

  $$
  \hspace{0.3em}\answer{P(x) =-\dfrac{2295}{26}x^3+\dfrac{47685}{26}x^2+\dfrac{475}{13}x}
  $$

- Differentiating $P(x)$ with respect to $x$, we get

  $$
  \hspace{0.3em}\answer{P'(x) =-\dfrac{6885}{26}x^2+\dfrac{47685}{13}x+\dfrac{475}{13}}
  $$

- If we sketch the graph of $P(x)$, the maximum profit occurs at point
A.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/dd6dcb9f-6f6a-4d52-86ef-4383fc6f3f51/images/01769894-ccf2-4567-9e25-00dfe1fa2901/5541c9fa3d0d1b43403859281edadfc0d340eef4.svg)


  Using G.D.C. to find the coordinates of A, we get

  $$
  x=13.9, \text{ and } P(x)\approx 118\,000
  $$

  Hence,
  The maximum profit will occur when the owner buys
$\hspace{0.4em}\answer{13\,900}\hspace{0.4em}$ souvenirs.
The resulting profit will be approximately
$\hspace{0.35em}\answer{\$118\,000.}$

list.title: Question 79
list.content:
The axis of symmetry of the graph of a quadratic function has equation
$x = \dfrac{3}{2}$.

- Draw the axis of symmetry on the grid below. [1]

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3b8f30f-dfd0-4c3d-af10-599523d5bfc7/images/8127e62b-8e3d-4e6a-800c-1ba598460cd3/095afe930760d162dfc8b9c36b42836af719a0ca.svg)



The graph of the quadratic function intersects the $x$-axis at the point
P$(-1,0)$. There is a second point, Q , at
which the graph of the quadratic function intersects the $x$-axis.

- Mark and label P and Q on the grid above. [1]


The graph of the quadratic function has equation $y = -x^2+bx+c$, where
$b,c \in \mathbb{Z}$.

- 
  - Find the value of $b$ and the value of $c$.
  - Find the coordinates of the vertex, M.
  - Draw the graph of the quadratic function on the grid above.
[4]
list.markScheme:
- If we draw the axis of symmetry on the grid below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3b8f30f-dfd0-4c3d-af10-599523d5bfc7/images/675f3abb-838e-4191-9b73-48d678ab9e7c/251642e55ba01124027bed7ddba72f11d48d8750.svg)


- The $x$-coordinate of $Q$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  x &= \dfrac{3}{2} + \left[\dfrac{3}{2}-(-1)\right] \\[6pt]
  &= 4\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, if we mark and label P and Q on the grid
below, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3b8f30f-dfd0-4c3d-af10-599523d5bfc7/images/ad959939-6aee-4367-b94d-7bb2b0d330f5/1fa563586fbd8e498bbc0f6a90199f2a3a99e7f7.svg)


- 
  - Using the coordinates of P, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.1em} 0 &= -(-1)^2 + b(-1) + c \\[6pt]
    0 &= -1 - b + c \\[6pt]
    1 &= -b + c \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Using the coordinates of
Q, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{1.6em} 0 &= -(4)^2 + b(4) + c \\[6pt]
    0 &= -16 + 4b + c \\[6pt]
    16 &= 4b + c \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence, solving the system
of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $b$ and $c$, we find

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{10em} \answer{b = 3}\hspace{0.75em}\text{ and }\hspace{0.75em}\answer{c = 4}\hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
    $$

  - Evaluating $y = -x^2 + 3x + 4$ for $x = 3/2 = 1.5$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{3.2em} y &= -(1.5)^2 + 3(1.5) + 4 \\[6pt]
    &= 6.25\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of M are
$\answer{(1,5,6.25)}$
  - If we draw the graph of $y = -x^2 + 3x + 4$ on the grid below,
we obtain

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f3b8f30f-dfd0-4c3d-af10-599523d5bfc7/images/35a967a1-1150-4aa0-a4fd-7d63f734e780/db963f9fd832653990678f1ba763db2a3974d991.svg)

list.title: Question 80
list.content:
The distance travelled, $d$, in meters, of a freely falling object is
proportional to the square of the time of the fall, $t$, in seconds.
A football dropped from the top of a school building falls a distance of
$19.6\text{ m}$ in the first $2$ seconds.

- Show that $d(t)=4.9t^2$. [2]

- Sketch the curve of $d$ for $t>0$, clearly showing the point
$(2,19.6)$. [2]


The distance covered, $s$, in meters, by a quad-copter drone undertaking
a vertical landing can be modelled by $s(t) = 8t$, where $t$ is the time
in seconds after the landing commences.
The football is dropped at the same time as the drone commences a
landing from the same height of the school building.
The football covers more distance than the drone when $t>p$.

- Find the value of $p$.   [2]
list.markScheme:
- Since $d$ varies proportionally with the square of $t$, we can state

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  d&=kt^2 \quad \text{[where k is a constant]}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have
$d=19.6 \text{ m}$ when $t=2\text{ s}$. We can use these to find
$k$:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  19.6 &= k(2)^{2}\hspace{3.8cm}\\[6pt]
  k&=4.9\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, we have shown

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{-7em}\answer{d=4.9t^2}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using GDC, we can plot the curve of $d(t)=4.9t^2$ for $t>0$, as
shown
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/08b312a2-f2be-4c99-a017-56011a6e21b2/images/14d89890-1629-4583-8dca-99e74de71942/523fcfa1c1e8c9a28b03f2d2499ceebab285f5d8.svg)


- The curves of $d(t)=4.9t^2$ and $s(t)=8t$ are plotted on the graph
below
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/08b312a2-f2be-4c99-a017-56011a6e21b2/images/ff8238cb-8231-4138-b80c-2159b3626395/f8c3444e7186ece84caeb418dfee107029e62cc6.svg)


  From the graph, $d(t) > s(t)$ when $t>1.63$. Hence,
$\answer{p=1.63}$

list.title: Question 81
list.content:
The security personnel at the entry of a rural campground activate a
siren to alert campers when a wild animal is spotted nearby. The sound
intensity, $I$, of the siren varies inversely with the square of the
distance from the siren, $d$. When initially testing the siren, the
security personnel found that at a distance of $3$ metres from the
siren, the sound intensity is $5$ watts per square metre
$(\text{Wm}^{-2})$.

- Show that $I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}$. [2]

- Sketch the curve of $I$ for $d>0$, labelling the point $(3,5)$.
[2]


The campers can only hear the siren if the sound intensity at their
location is greater than $1.2\times10^{-5} \text{Wm}^{-2}$.

- Find the minimum distance, in kilometers, from the siren where the
campers can no longer hear the siren. [2]
list.markScheme:
- Since $I$ varies inversely with the square of $d$, we can state

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I&=\dfrac{k}{d^2} \quad \text{[where k is a constant]}\end{aligned}
  $$

  We have $I=5 \text{ Wm}^{-2}$ when $d=3\text{ m}$. We can use these to find $k$:

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 &= \dfrac{k}{3^2}\hspace{3.8cm}\\[6pt]
  k&=45\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, we have shown

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \tcbhighmath{I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Using GDC, we can plot the curve of $I=\dfrac{45}{d^2}$ for $d>0$, as shown
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/151224cf-2f80-4345-b68e-a612caa31abb/images/612a624d-0502-474e-802f-6124a743e115/AI875.PNG)


- Campers can only hear the siren when $I>1.2\times 10^{-5}$. Therefore

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  I &> 1.2\times 10^{-5} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{45}{d^2} &> 1.2\times 10^{-5}\\[6pt]
  \dfrac{45}{1.2\times 10^{-5}}&>d^2\\[6pt]
  d &< \sqrt{\dfrac{45}{1.2\times 10^{-5}}}\\[6pt]
  d &< 1936.49\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, the minimum distance from the siren is $\answer{1.94 \text{ km}}$

list.title: Question 82
list.content:
The mean depth, $D$, in metres, of a mountain lake fluctuates in a
yearly cycle and can be modelled by the function

$$
D(t) = a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(k t) + b,
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time,
in months, since the beginning of an autumn season.
The mean depth of the lake on month $1$ is
$33.2$ m and on month $5$ is
$22.8$ m.

- Find the value of $k$, in degrees. [2]

- Set up a pair of equations and find the value of $a$ and the value
of $b$. Give your answers correct to the nearest integer.
[3]

- Hence find the mean depth of the lake on month $8$. [2]

- Draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ on the grid below, for one full year,
indicating clearly the minimum and maximum points.
[4]

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/650b6656-5f6c-4fd2-980c-ceab4bbe6228/22e9fb4574cbc4ff36d7eb0e402d77e50876a875.svg)


- Determine the total amount of time in one year that the mean depth is expected to be lower than 26 metres. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The period of $D$ is $12$ months.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k &= \dfrac{\ang{360}}{12} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= \ang{30}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(1) &= 33.2 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 1) + b &= 33.2 \\[6pt]
  0.866a + b &= 33.2 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(5) &= 22.8 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 5) + b &= 22.8 \\[6pt]
  -0.866a + b &= 22.8 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the
system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.8em} \answer{a \approx 6} \hspace{1em}\text{ and }\hspace{1em} \answer{b \approx 28} \hspace{3.8em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $D(t)$ for $t = 8$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  D(8) &= 6\cos\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{30}\hspace{-0.15em}\times8) + 28 \hspace{0.7em} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 25 \text{ m}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The min and max values of the cosine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max mean depths of the lake during the year are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{10.2em} D_{\text{min}} &= 6(-1)+28 \\[6pt]
  &= 22 \text{ m} \hspace{1em} [\text{when } t = (0.5)12 = 9] \\[15pt]
  D_{\text{max}} &= 6(+1)+28 \\[6pt]
  &= 34 \text{ m} \hspace{1em} [\text{when } t = (0)12 = 0\hspace{0.25em}\&\hspace{0.25em}t = (1)12 = 12]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we draw the graph of $y = D(t)$ on the grid below, for
$0 \leq t \leq 12$, indicating the points A$(0,34)$, B$(12,34)$ and
C$(6,22)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/2b12daf7-2a64-4082-be83-d94cf2bb913d/73e28209b510fb17f449ac18e686993a5d03e3ef.svg)


- Adding the graph of $y=26$ to our solution from part (d), we can find the points of intersection:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/892d8911-e718-441b-bcaf-1a5740d0392e/images/afc9ddca-9147-42e2-83ce-681f27150723/ai177a.PNG)



  $$
  \begin{align*}
  8.351-3.649 &= 4.702
  \end{align*}
  $$

  The mean depth of the lake is lower than $26$ metres for approximately $\answer{\text{$4.70$ months.}}$

list.title: Question 83
list.content:
A new class of antibiotics is studied in the medical research center.
Antibiotics are applied to a pure culture of bacteria. The number of
bacteria, $N$, present in the culture $t$ hours after the start of the
experiment are recorded. The results are shown in the table below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8c408642-a9dc-4bbb-957a-5d6a5fe9857e/images/7ce99e72-9c18-4516-b553-7fa9196ca477/e1fb081fc41a9cc621eeb3b2ff28f126bbc93514.svg)



- Complete the third row of the table above. [2]

- Draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, scaling the axes if
needed. [3]

- State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your
scatter
diagram from part (b). [1]


A researcher in the center claims that the number of bacteria, $N$, left
in the culture $\text{after}$ applying antibiotics can be
modelled by an exponential function of the form $N(t) = a\times b^t$,
where $a$ and $b$ are positive constants.

- Explain why the researcher is correct. [4]

- Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Calculating the values of $\log N$, we get

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8c408642-a9dc-4bbb-957a-5d6a5fe9857e/images/520e95cb-de01-4462-a729-e7b911bbcb85/61b4f3ec9ac851d948d8978ac81720c3afe52589.svg)



- If we draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8c408642-a9dc-4bbb-957a-5d6a5fe9857e/images/fefd2280-20f5-4296-828e-ec96dc4feb80/e884512675852ac6da9bd0f7c67f1081c0ab4d85.svg)


- $\answer{\text{Linear model}}$
- Using the properties of exponents, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.2em} \log N(t) &= mt + c \hspace{3em} [\text{by parts (b) and (c)}] \\[8pt]
  10^{mt+c} &= N(t) \hspace{3em} [\text{by definition of log}] \\[8pt]
  (10^{mt})(10^c) &= N(t) \\[8pt]
  N(t) &= (10^c)(10^{m})^t\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we obtain
$N(t) = a\times b^t$ for $a = 10^c$ and $b = 10^m$.
- The equation of the regression line of $\log N$ on $t$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11em} \log N(t) &= -0.13765t + 4.84028 \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} a &= 10^{4.84028} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 69\hspace{0.15em}200}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.9em} b &= 10^{-0.13765} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 0.728}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 84
list.content:
The amount of water, $A$, in thousands of litres, available in a water
tank located on a farm fluctuates in a yearly cycle and can be modelled
by the function

$$
A(t) = a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(k t) + b,
$$

where $t$ is the elapsed time, in weeks, since the start of the
year.
The amount of water available in the tank on week $6$ is $24$ thousand
litres and on week $31$ is $9.2$ thousand
litres.

- Find the value of $k$, in degrees, assuming there are $52$ whole
weeks in a year.[2]

- Set up a pair of equations to find the value of $a$ and the value of
$b$. Give your answers correct to the nearest integer.
[3]

- Hence find the amount of water available in the tank in week $42$.
[2]

- Draw the graph of $y = A(t)$ on the grid below, for one full year,
indicating clearly the minimum and maximum points.
[4]

  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f9ea1ac-4ddd-4bad-86a6-cabf74ce33e5/images/e6db81cc-44d6-4dec-bb02-b8db7bb46b78/a35842049aa426b4bf5aefe8b287a6da9db53a2d.svg)


- Determine the total number of weeks that the amount of water in the tank is at least $24\,000$ litres. Give your answer to the nearest week. [2]
list.markScheme:
- The period of $A$ is $52$ weeks.
Hence we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  k &= \dfrac{\ang{360}}{52} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx \ang{6.92}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  A(6) &= 24 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{6.92}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 6) + b &= 24 \\[6pt]
  0.663a + b &= 24 \qref{(1)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  A(31) &= 9.2 \hspace{3em} \\[6pt]
  a\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{6.92}\hspace{-0.15em}\times 31) + b &= 9.2 \\[6pt]
  -0.567a + b &= 9.2 \qref{(2)}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, solving the
system of linear equations $(1)$-$(2)$ for $a$ and $b$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11.5em} \answer{a \approx 12} \hspace{1em}\text{ and }\hspace{1em} \answer{b \approx 16} \hspace{3.5em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

- Evaluating $A(t)$ for $t = 42$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.5em} A(42) &= 12\sin\hspace{0.15em}(\ang{6.92}\hspace{-0.15em}\times42) + 16 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 4.77 \text{ thousand litres}}\end{aligned}
  $$

- The min and max values of the sine function are $-1$ and $+1$.
Hence the min and max amounts of water in the tank available during
the year are

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.3em} A_{\text{min}} &= 12(-1)+16 \\[6pt]
  &= 4 \text{ thousand litres} \hspace{2.5em} [\text{when } t = (0.75)52 = 39] \\[15pt]
  A_{\text{max}} &= 12(+1)+16 \\[6pt]
  &= 28 \text{ thousand litres} \hspace{2em} [\text{when } t = (0.25)52 = 13]\end{aligned}
  $$

  If we draw the graph of $y = A(t)$ on the grid below, for
$0 \leq t \leq 52$, indicating the points P$(13,28)$ and Q$(39,4)$,
we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f9ea1ac-4ddd-4bad-86a6-cabf74ce33e5/images/b8498a75-a823-45e9-98f9-710beed4d209/8814e237c9bc7b3142ac40e7f50be90d39e62a05.svg)


- Adding the graph of $y=24$ to our solution from part (d), we can find the points of intersection:
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9f9ea1ac-4ddd-4bad-86a6-cabf74ce33e5/images/ebef324b-3baf-41cb-98f1-619d4c70d32a/ai176a.PNG)


  The amount of water in the tank is at least $24\,000$ litres for $\answer{\text{$14$ weeks}}$ (to the nearest week).

list.title: Question 85
list.content:
A particular species of microbes is studied in the laboratory. Microbes
are grown under controlled conditions in pure culture. The number of
microbes, $N$, present in the culture $t$ hours after the start of the
experiment are recorded. The results are shown in the table below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/e0c72216-8582-4a43-b865-6568739b5e03/05f74794f9493b7052849a256cb95a218dff9b51.svg)



- Complete the third row of the table above. [2]

- Draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, scaling the axes if
needed. [3]

- State the type of model that best fits the data displayed on your
scatter
diagram from part (b). [1]


A scientist in the laboratory claims that the number of microbes, $N$,
grown in the laboratory during the experiment can be modelled by an
exponential function of the form $N(t) = a\times b^t$, where $a$ and $b$
are positive constants.

- Explain why the scientist is correct. [4]

- Find the value of $a$ and the value of $b$. [4]
list.markScheme:
- Calculating the values of $\log N$, we get

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/04df3b88-45a9-4949-aa9e-88b0f0bf335c/6cf620ba27d00fb0d7be6bd8c31f6e9e22c0c9ce.svg)



- If we draw a scatter diagram of $\log N$ versus $t$, we
have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e9b46dc9-0930-45e2-82d6-cef1f0c4947c/images/18131649-4993-445a-99d1-5cf1380f097e/73d2d06aa23839e33065bdf471930d83ad8030b6.svg)


- $\answer{\text{Linear model}}$
- Using the properties of exponents, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{9.2em} \log N(t) &= mt + c \hspace{3em} [\text{by parts (b) and (c)}] \\[8pt]
  10^{mt+c} &= N(t) \hspace{3em} [\text{by definition of log}] \\[8pt]
  (10^{mt})(10^c) &= N(t) \\[8pt]
  N(t) &= (10^c)(10^{m})^t\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we obtain
$N(t) = a\times b^t$ for $a = 10^c$ and $b = 10^m$.
- The equation of the regression line of $\log N$ on $t$ is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{11em} \log N(t) &= 0.14521t + 1.69035 \hspace{2em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using part (d), we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.2em} a &= 10^{1.69035} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 49.0}\end{aligned}
  $$

  and

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{0.3em} b &= 10^{0.14521} \\[6pt]
  &\answer{\approx 1.40}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 86
list.content:
A right cylinder has height $h$ mm and diameter $x$ mm. The volume of
this cylinder is equal to $45$ mm$^3$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff24aae3-1825-4594-84b1-18ff6ebb70d3/images/efc9fbc4-0075-415f-b8c9-1a1def8352df/9aebb1d3e12c9fb1c552ed279ae0c28d1ca125c3.svg)


The total surface area, $A$, of the cylinder can be expressed as
$A = \dfrac{\pi}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{k}{x}$.

- Find the value of $k$. [4]

- Find the value of $x$ that makes the total surface area a minimum.
[2]
list.markScheme:
- Using the volume of a right cylinder formula, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  V &= \pi r^2h \\[6pt]
  45 &= \pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]^2\hspace{-0.2em}h \\[3pt]
  45 &= \dfrac{\pi x^2h}{4} \\[6pt]
  h &= \dfrac{180}{\pi x^2} \end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence the total surface area is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{8em} A(x) &= [\text{top \& bottom area}] + [\text{curved surface area}] \\[16pt]
  &=  2\pi r^2 + 2\pi rh \\[9pt]
  &= 2\pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]^2 + 2\pi\bigg[\dfrac{x}{2}\bigg]\bigg[\dfrac{180}{\pi x^2}\bigg] \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{\pi}{2}x^2 + \dfrac{180}{x}\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{k = 180}$
- If we sketch the graph of $y = A(x)$, for $x > 0$ [by using
G.D.C.], we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff24aae3-1825-4594-84b1-18ff6ebb70d3/images/70443638-b03e-4b02-9371-621e475b9a63/10ad2caa42e46f8e9db41f9ae6642694c0b81ac1.svg)


  Hence
$\answer{x \approx 3.86 \text{  mm}}$
makes the total surface area a minimum.

list.title: Question 87
list.content:
Peter wants to reach a rock, located $5$ km away
from his current position, using the strategy outlined below.
Every hour Peter approaches the rock by a fixed percent of the remaining
distance to the rock.
The distance, $D$, in kilometres, Peter has travelled from his original
position, can be modelled by the exponential function

$$
\begin{aligned}
D(t) = a + b\big(k^{-t}\big), \hspace{0.5em} t\geq 0, \end{aligned}
$$

where $t$ is the time, in hours, since Peter started moving.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/801847f8-3a4e-4e44-b8ec-eefd0e4a732e/images/f49c99b3-6084-4cce-b203-48eef7cf3293/819ba2cfeb3383629fe25649fde3301bcf8c76d4.svg)



- Explain why $a= 5$. [2]

- Find the value of $b$. [2]


After one hour, the distance from Peter to the rock is
$3.75$ km.

- Find the value of $k$. [2]

- Find the distance between Peter and the rock after $4$
hours. [2]


Peter can be heard when shouting from $200$ metres away.

- Calculate the time it takes until someone standing on the
rock can hear Peter shouting. Round your answer correct to the
nearest hour.
[3]
list.markScheme:
- We have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/801847f8-3a4e-4e44-b8ec-eefd0e4a732e/images/749982c8-e46c-4506-bf93-4534155f5e67/284ba0b0f6db44c91e038d4ec5486789b5846da8.svg)


  On the other hand, we know Peter will not travel more than
$5$ km.
  Hence we must have $a = 5$.
- Solving the equation $D(0) = 0$ for $t$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 + b\big(k^{0}\big) &= 0 \hspace{1.6em} \\[6pt]
  5 + b &= 0 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{2.8em} \answer{b = -5}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(1) = 5 - 3.75 = 1.25$ for $k$, we obtain

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5 - 5\big(k^{-1}\big) &= 1.25 \hspace{2.35em} \\[10pt]
  5 - \dfrac{5}{k} &= \dfrac{5}{4} \\[6pt]
  1 - \dfrac{1}{k} &= \dfrac{1}{4} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{3}{4} &= \dfrac{1}{k} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \hspace{0.8em} \answer{k = \dfrac{4}{3}}
  $$

- Evaluating $D(t)$ for $t = 4$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.4em} D(4) &= 5 - 5\hspace{-0.15em}\left(\dfrac{4}{3}\right)^{-4} \\[6pt]
  &\approx 3.42\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, the distance between Peter and
the rock after $4$ hours is

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  5  - D(4) &= 5 - 3.42 \\[6pt]
  &\answer{= 1.58 \text{ km}} \hspace{1.4em}\end{aligned}
  $$

- Solving the equation $D(t) = 5 - 0.2 = 4.80$ for $t$, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{6.8em} 5 - 5\big(k^{-t}\big) &= 4.80 \hspace{1em} \\[6pt]
  t &\approx 11.2 \hspace{3em} [\text{by using G.D.C.}]\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence it takes
$\answer{11 \text{ hours}}$
until someone on the rock can hear Peter shouting.
